commit_message:
Add functional test for project CA

Added a test that whole scenario for the add project CA/remove project
CA.

On the other hand, this fixed an issue in the add/remove project
CA controllers.

Change-Id: Ic1963ab32fe28925361ebe9760d4a8a5d32b5f0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/83/222583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from functionaltests.common import config CONF = config.get_config() admin_a = CONF.rbac_users.admin_a creator_a = CONF.rbac_users.creator_aBARBICAN_SRV_CONF = cert_interface.CONF def is_plugin_enabled(plugin): return plugin in BARBICAN_SRV_CONF.certificate.enabled_certificate_plugins def depends_on_ca_plugins(*plugins): def depends_on_ca_plugins_decorator(function): def wrapper(instance, *args, **kwargs): plugins_enabled = (is_plugin_enabled(p) for p in plugins) testtools.skipIf( not all(plugins_enabled), "The following plugin(s) need to be enabled: ".format(plugins)) function(instance, *args, **kwargs) return wrapper return depends_on_ca_plugins_decoratorclass CATestCommon(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(CATestCommon, self).setUp() self.order_behaviors = order_behaviors.OrderBehaviors(self.client) self.ca_behaviors = ca_behaviors.CABehaviors(self.client) # we need to prime the pump ie. populate the CA table by sending # in an order (just in case) self.send_test_order() def send_test_order(self, ca_ref=None): test_model = order_models.OrderModel(**self.simple_cmc_data) test_model.meta['request_data'] = base64.b64encode( certutil.create_good_csr()) if ca_ref is not None: ca_id = hrefs.get_ca_id_from_ref(ca_ref) test_model.meta['ca_id'] = ca_id create_resp, order_ref = self.order_behaviors.create_order(test_model) self.assertEqual(202, create_resp.status_code) self.assertIsNotNone(order_ref) def get_root_ca_ref(self, ca_plugin_name, ca_plugin_id): (resp, cas, total, next_ref, prev_ref) = self.ca_behaviors.get_cas() for item in cas: ca = self.ca_behaviors.get_ca(item) if ca.model.plugin_name == ca_plugin_name: if ca.model.plugin_ca_id == ca_plugin_id: return item return None class CertificateAuthoritiesTestCase(CATestCommon): def get_snakeoil_subca_model(self): parent_ca_ref = self.get_root_ca_ref( ca_plugin_name=('barbican.plugin.snakeoil_ca.' 'SnakeoilCACertificatePlugin'), ca_plugin_id="Snakeoil CA") @depends_on_ca_plugins('snakeoil_ca', 'simple_certificate') def test_list_snakeoil_and_simple_cert_cas(self): """Test if backend loads these specific CAs Since the standard gate works with the snakeoil CA and the simple_certificate CA. This test is just to make sure that these two are specifically loaded. """ (resp, cas, total, next_ref, prev_ref) = self.ca_behaviors.get_cas() self.assertGreater(total, 2) @depends_on_ca_plugins('snakeoil_ca') @depends_on_ca_plugins('snakeoil_ca') @depends_on_ca_plugins('snakeoil_ca') class ProjectCATestCase(CATestCommon): def setUp(self): super(ProjectCATestCase, self).setUp() @depends_on_ca_plugins('snakeoil_ca', 'simple_certificate') def test_addition_of_project_ca_affects_getting_ca_list(self): # Getting list of CAs should get the total configured CAs (resp, cas, initial_total, _, __) = self.ca_behaviors.get_cas() self.assertGreater(initial_total, 0) # Set project CA ca_ref = self.get_root_ca_ref( ca_plugin_name=('barbican.plugin.snakeoil_ca.' 'SnakeoilCACertificatePlugin'), ca_plugin_id="Snakeoil CA") resp = self.ca_behaviors.add_ca_to_project(ca_ref, user_name=admin_a) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) # Getting list of CAs should get only the project CA (resp, cas, project_ca_total, _, __) = self.ca_behaviors.get_cas( user_name=creator_a) self.assertEqual(1, project_ca_total) # Remove project CA resp = self.ca_behaviors.remove_ca_from_project(ca_ref, user_name=admin_a) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) # Getting list of CAs should get the total configured CAs (as seen # before) (resp, cas, final_total, _, __) = self.ca_behaviors.get_cas() self.assertGreater(initial_total, final_total)

commit_message:
Pin version of oslo.config and oslo.utils

'python-keystoneclient' is incompatible with the newest 'oslo.config' and
'oslo.utils' located at PyPI. Pin usable version of 'oslo.config' and
'oslo.utils' to be less than 2.0.0

Change-Id: I7f7371f899c8141d9184d2035400d5058766b8cb
Closes-Bug: #1477066
(cherry picked from commit 7a29d1ac9b0d39290a45b4150b9157302ae0bf57)

commit_message:
Remove existing timeout and increase time

If the original Monasca roles have a timeout set it brakes the
Ceilosca script since there will be two timout set in the same
command.

This patch removes any pre-existing timeout before inserting the
new one set to 600s.

Change-Id: I7ce3c8f360643fdcd57b350cda3270018b7b2d6e
co-author: Steven Irvin <steven.irvin@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-ceilometer refs/changes/94/224894/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sed -i.bak 's/ timeout=[0-9]\+//' $filename sed -i '/get_url:/s/$/ timeout=600/' $filename

commit_message:
Refactor set_configs.py

This refactor brings the logging in line with the rest of Kolla.
The fucntion names were updated to reflect thier new role.

Additionally, it fixes several issues with the permissions which
currently break all containers that use set_configs.py

It will also work with source being a directory or a file now.

Change-Id: I4a197a343e3baf3bd31532debdff5972adb8aefa
Partially-Implements: blueprint replace-config-external

subject: stable/juno: adjust python-ceilometerclient version range
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-17 16:13:40.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/a54948766e4835bc46299d84fd45926881189399', 'message': "stable/juno: adjust python-ceilometerclient version range

This is the stable/juno portion of the series to decouple stable/juno
and stable/kilo for python-ceilometerclient.

The adjusted stable/kilo version range is in change
I6791b40a3022cb923ddef4bcf5fb75f9024e07eb. Basically stable/kilo will
use the 1.1.x releases and stable/juno needs to use the 1.0.x releases.

We have to block 1.0.12 since it has uncapped oslo.utils which breaks
with capped oslo.utils from server projects that are synced with
stable/juno g-r, like horizon.

We have to block 1.0.13 and 1.0.14 since those versions have kilo-level
dependent versions which conflict with stable/juno g-r dependent
versions.

The plan is to sync g-r stable/juno to python-ceilometerclient which is
change Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9, and that depends on
this change because otherwise ceilometer on stable/juno requires
python-ceilometerclient<1.0.13 and we can't get
Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9 to pass Jenkins.

Once this change syncs to ceilometer on stable/juno we can get
Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9 to pass CI and release that as
1.0.15, which falls within this range in g-r for stable/juno but won't
fall into the range for stable/kilo g-r.

Whew...

Partial-Bug: #1494516

Change-Id: Ie8151e79928b1cd8a2701b05fc510a36a15a75d1
"}]
commit_message:
stable/juno: adjust python-ceilometerclient version range

This is the stable/juno portion of the series to decouple stable/juno
and stable/kilo for python-ceilometerclient.

The adjusted stable/kilo version range is in change
I6791b40a3022cb923ddef4bcf5fb75f9024e07eb. Basically stable/kilo will
use the 1.1.x releases and stable/juno needs to use the 1.0.x releases.

We have to block 1.0.12 since it has uncapped oslo.utils which breaks
with capped oslo.utils from server projects that are synced with
stable/juno g-r, like horizon.

We have to block 1.0.13 and 1.0.14 since those versions have kilo-level
dependent versions which conflict with stable/juno g-r dependent
versions.

The plan is to sync g-r stable/juno to python-ceilometerclient which is
change Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9, and that depends on
this change because otherwise ceilometer on stable/juno requires
python-ceilometerclient<1.0.13 and we can't get
Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9 to pass Jenkins.

Once this change syncs to ceilometer on stable/juno we can get
Iee95922e66b4885f720499d912ff1926019b67c9 to pass CI and release that as
1.0.15, which falls within this range in g-r for stable/juno but won't
fall into the range for stable/kilo g-r.

Whew...

Partial-Bug: #1494516

Change-Id: Ie8151e79928b1cd8a2701b05fc510a36a15a75d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/07/224807/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): For python-ceilometerclient, we block 1.0.12 because it has # uncapped oslo.utils which conflicts with projects that have capped oslo.utils # here. We block 1.0.13 and 1.0.14 because they have stable/kilo level # dependent versions, which conflicts with stable/juno dependent versions and # caps. python-ceilometerclient>=1.0.6,!=1.0.12,!=1.0.13,!=1.0.14,<1.1.0

subject: WIP: Fix to run v2.1 comp mode tests with v2 sample files
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-17 02:17:43.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/functional/api_sample_tests/test_extension_info.py', 'nova/tests/functional/api_sample_tests/test_used_limits.py', 'nova/tests/functional/api_sample_tests/test_virtual_interfaces.py', 'nova/tests/functional/api_sample_tests/test_limits.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/791baa283515236f702f8c9d7e798034af1f1b4f', 'message': 'WIP: Fix to run v2.1 comp mode tests with v2 sample files

- rate limit bits
- extension info

For above cases, their functional tests has separate sample files

This will make sure v2.1 comp mode behaves same as v2 APIs.

Change-Id: I97bd0562dabc619e15e15ce7f08ee96fa0feea00
'}]
commit_message:
WIP: Fix to run v2.1 comp mode tests with v2 sample files

There are some cases where v2.1 is different than v2.0 for example
- VIF net-id
- rate limit bits
- extension info

For above cases, their functional tests has separate sample files
for v2 and v2.1 tests.
As we have tests for v2.1 comp mode also which are supposed to be run
against v2 sample files instead of v2.1 one.

This will make sure v2.1 comp mode behaves same as v2 APIs.

Change-Id: I97bd0562dabc619e15e15ce7f08ee96fa0feea00

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/designate/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================= Designate to Designate driver ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/designate/+spec/d2d-driver Add a driver that uses a Designate service and SECONDARY zones like we do with Dyn / Akamai. Problem description =================== We want to be able to use a instance of a Designate service to act as the target for our zones. Proposed change =============== Create a driver that utilizes the SECONDARY zones feature of Designate. API Changes ----------- N/A Central Changes --------------- N/A Storage Changes --------------- N/A Other Changes ------------- Add driver 'designate' to designate.backends using v2 api and secondary zones. subject: Eventlet green threads not released back to pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-26 03:07:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/bef9c2b89a11457d661238d6a7f5bd68c9f17cfa', 'message': "Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of
time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s
Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).
Added client_socket_timeout option (default=900).
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I303d87addeed8b103eeb26dbcc48e3acce06ee6a

commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of
time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s
Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).
Added client_socket_timeout option (default=900).
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I303d87addeed8b103eeb26dbcc48e3acce06ee6a
Closes-Bug: #1361360
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/74/144074/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: wsgi_elt_opts = [ cfg.BoolOpt('wsgi_keep_alive', default=True, help="If False, closes the client socket connection " "explicitly."), cfg.IntOpt('client_socket_timeout', default=900, help="Timeout for client connections' socket operations. " "If an incoming connection is idle for this number of " "seconds it will be closed. A value of '0' means " "wait forever."), ] wsgi_elt_group = cfg.OptGroup('eventlet_opts') cfg.CONF.register_group(wsgi_elt_group) cfg.CONF.register_opts(wsgi_elt_opts, group=wsgi_elt_group) yield 'eventlet_opts', wsgi_elt_opts self.client_socket_timeout = cfg.CONF.client_socket_timeout or None debug=cfg.CONF.debug, keepalive=cfg.CONF.wsgi_keep_alive, socket_timeout=self.client_socket_timeout)

commit_message:
OSSN - Cached Keystone Tokens

Security note for keystonemiddleware without TRL checking

Co-authored-by: Doug Chivers <doug.chivers@hp.com>

Closes Bug: #1435530

Change-Id: I8272a0e6e985a55e185f21f2e3c49045de1069bc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/22/219922/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Cached Keystone tokens may be accepted after revocation --- ### Summary ### Keystone Token Caching is used to reduce the load on keystone services, by default tokens are valid for 300 seconds, to enable revocation of cached tokens, Token Revocation Lists (TRLs) are used, with a default lifetime of 10 seconds. This creates a misleading expectation that revoked tokens will not be accepted more than 10 seconds after revocation, however the maximum lifespan of a cached token must be assumed to be the cache duration. System owners should make a risk based decision to balance token lifespan with performance requirements and if the use of revoked tokens is an unacceptable risk then caching should be disabled. ### Affected Services / Software ### Nova, Kilo, Juno ### Discussion ### In previous versions of OpenStack, the Keystone middleware Token Revocation List (TRLs) lifespan was set to 5 minutes (300 seconds), this could allow an attacker to utilize a compromised token for up to 5 minutes before the TRL expired. This was corrected in Juno, where the default TRL lifetime was reduced to 10 seconds. However, the addition of a token to a TRL does not guarantee that cached tokens will be rejected, so the attack window for a revoked token must be assumed to be the lifespan of the cached token. System owners should weigh the risk of an attacker using a revoked token versus the performance implications of reducing the token cache lifetime. ### Recommended Actions ### - (Icehouse and earlier) Verify that the keystone middleware revocation_cache_time is set to 10 seconds not 300 seconds (as patched in Juno). - Review the implications of the default 300 second token lifetime and any risks associated with the use of revoked certificates for up to that lifetime. If this is unacceptable, reduce the lifetime to reduce the attack window, or disable token caching entirely. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0056 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-keystoneclient/+bug/1287301 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

commit_message:
Add support for using HTTP POST in VmdkWriteHandle

The NFC protocol requires HTTP POST with content type
'application/x-vnd.vmware-streamVmdk' in order to provision virtual
disks in thin format. This patch allows clients to specify the HTTP verb
when using VmdkWriteHandle and thus enables thin provisioning.

Change-Id: Ie11c2bfbbb1ca71e9d35c9407f871214b6aa0e9a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.vmware refs/changes/58/224558/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_write_connection(self, method, url, conn = self._create_connection(url, method, cacerts, ssl_thumbprint) self._conn = self._create_write_connection('PUT', self._url, vmdk_size, http_method='PUT'): :param http_method: either PUT or POST if http_method == 'PUT': overwrite = 't' content_type = 'binary/octet-stream' elif http_method == 'POST': overwrite = None content_type = 'application/x-vnd.vmware-streamVmdk' else: raise ValueError('http_method must be either PUT or POST') self._conn = self._create_write_connection(http_method, self._url, overwrite=overwrite, content_type=content_type,
deleted_lines: def _create_write_connection(self, url, conn = self._create_connection(url, 'PUT', cacerts, ssl_thumbprint) self._conn = self._create_write_connection(self._url, vmdk_size): octet_stream = 'binary/octet-stream' self._conn = self._create_write_connection(self._url, overwrite='t', content_type=octet_stream,

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 21:37:13.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/port_chain_system_and_flow.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-sfc/commit/1d3a309e3a03f753227644d0c8fc751949b4ffe7', 'message': "Update hyperlinks from Gerrit to rendered docs

This change replaces links to Gerrit changes with links to the
rendered HTML documentation on docs.openstack.org as well as
minor gramatical nitpicking.

I think we have a chicken and egg situation. The infra change to
enable docs generation [1] has been merged but the docs aren't
in the expected location [2] yet. I think this is because the

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221589/
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-sfc/portchain-ovs-driver-agent.html

commit_message:
Update hyperlinks from Gerrit to rendered docs

This change replaces links to Gerrit changes with links to the
rendered HTML documentation on docs.openstack.org as well as
minor gramatical nitpicking.

I think we have a chicken and egg situation. The infra change to
enable docs generation [1] has been merged but the docs aren't
in the expected location [2] yet. I think this is because the
Jenkins job will only run when a change is merged and nothing
has been merged in the networking-sfc repo since the infra
change. I believe that merging this change should trigger the
Jenkins job which will create [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221589/
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-sfc/portchain-ovs-driver-agent.html

Change-Id: I20fb684fc9c8932ec1ea083ff9077e668cc2c1cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-sfc refs/changes/20/224320/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The Port chain specification [1]_ proposes a Neutron port based API forand related API work flow is needed to guide the code design.different service providers such as OVS Driver and/or different types ofdifferent drivers can provide different implementations for the serviceA separate "OVS Driver and Agent" specification [2]_ will describe in moreAgent spec [2]_ for more detail info... [1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-sfc/api.html .. [2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-sfc/portchain-ovs-driver-agent.html
deleted_lines: The Port chain specification [1]_. and [2]_. propose a Neutron port based API forand related API work flow are needed to guide the code design.different service providers, such as OVS Driver, different types ofdifferent drivers can provide different implementation for the serviceA separate "OVS Driver and Agent" specification [3]_. will describe in moreAgent spec [3]_. for more detail info... [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/192933/ .. [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204695/ .. [3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/208663/

subject: Add Cinder API wsgi application
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-10 14:07:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/afb53c455b144864dcd2adc6b96a4b9932bf83aa', 'message': 'WIP:Implement cinder API WSGI application under Apache/Nginx

Cinder API uses eventelt as a webserver and WSGI application
managing.This approach has some cons:

* Cinder API is deployed in other way as a common web application.
Apache/Nginx is generally used web servers for REST API application.

* Cinder API is runned as a separate service. It means that cloud
operator need to configure some software to monitor that API is running.

* Apache/Nginx works better under the real heavy load then eventlet.

This change adds cinder API application implemention to be possible run
cinder API under Apache/Nginx.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint: non-eventlet-wsgi-app

Change-Id: If877d700b0efaa5406efa8f8f17c5816928e83ce

Cinder API uses eventlet as a webserver and WSGI application
managing. This approach has some cons:

* Cinder API is deployed in other way as a common web application.
Apache/Nginx is generally used web servers for REST API application.

* Cinder API is run as a separate service. It means that cloud
operator need to configure some software to monitor that API is running.

* Apache/Nginx works better under the real heavy load then eventlet.

This change adds cinder API application implemention, so cinder API
can be run under Apache/Nginx.

To use c-api deployment under Apache in devstack assign
devstack var CINDER_USE_MOD_WSGI="True".
Related changes in devstack:
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204643/

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint: non-eventlet-wsgi-app

Change-Id: If877d700b0efaa5406efa8f8f17c5816928e83ce

commit_message:
Add Cinder API wsgi application

This change adds cinder API application, so cinder API can be run
under wsgi server(Apache, Nginx, etc). Eventlet will still be used
by default.

Cinder API with eventlet as a webserver and wsgi application
managing has some cons:

* Cinder API is deployed in other way as a common web application.
Apache/Nginx is generally used web servers for REST API application.

* Cinder API is run as a separate service. It means that cloud
operators need to configure some software to monitor that the API
is running.

* Apache/Nginx works better under the real heavy load than eventlet.

To use c-api deployment under Apache in devstack assign
devstack var CINDER_USE_MOD_WSGI="True".
Related changes in devstack:
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204643/

Cinder documentation on how deploy cinder API under Apache:
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/207020/

Patch for Infra to make it tested:
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/208498/

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint: non-eventlet-wsgi-app

Change-Id: If877d700b0efaa5406efa8f8f17c5816928e83ce

added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """Cinder OS API WSGI application.""" import sys import warnings from cinder import objects warnings.simplefilter('once', DeprecationWarning) from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from cinder import i18n i18n.enable_lazy() # Need to register global_opts from cinder.common import config # noqa from cinder.openstack.common.report import guru_meditation_report as gmr from cinder import rpc from cinder import version from cinder import wsgi CONF = cfg.CONF def _application(): objects.register_all() CONF(sys.argv[1:], project='cinder', version=version.version_string()) logging.setup(CONF, "cinder") gmr.TextGuruMeditation.setup_autorun(version) rpc.init(CONF) return wsgi.Loader().load_app(name='osapi_volume') application = _application()

Compute v2.1 docs clean up (part10) (os-volumes, os-snapshots)

Add os-volumes, os-snapshots
  this file (WADL, JSON) is based on v2 ext files.
     Changes   /v2 => /v2.1
               Remove xml sample, keep JSON sample only

p.s.
  os-snapshots are not listed in launchpad bug report.

commit_message:
v3 to v2 catalog conversion missing id

Keystonemiddleware's auth_token _v3_to_v2_catalog conversion is
dropping the id portion of the catalog during the conversion. This
makes sure the id is carried over.

Closes-Bug: #1421858

and edit_managed attributes.

commit_message:
Raise on RBAC error

Raises an InternalServerError on a problem creating the RBAC filter
rather than silently failing and allowing the search to continue.

Change-Id: I33878096f628be0e0e1af1466f6d44cd253c8a2e
Closes-Bug: #1492112
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/32/224332/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: msg = _("Error processing %s RBAC filter") % resource_type raise webob.exc.HTTPInternalServerError(explanation=msg)

In OVS agent segmentation_id can't be unicode None

change it to '0'

commit_message:
Updated requirements and unit tests config

Changes:

1) Updated from global requirements

2) Updated "run_tests.sh" script to be able to run unit tests
using Django 1.8.* removing "--verbosity" opt.

3) Added tox jobs 'py27dj17' and 'py27dj18' to be able to run
unit tests for Django 1.7.* and 1.8.* in separate envs.

Change-Id: I267c8e7a6cb8d67d7331f4f00cb79ad98832d0e7
Closes-Bug: #1496412

commit_message:
Removed bullets from example architectures

Removed bullets from the example architectures. Content has been rearranged
into logical paragraph under headings for each example.

Fixed typo in second example architecture.
Fixed typo in first example architecture.
Left aligned notes to avoid unnecessary blockquote.
Intended notes 2 spaces to fix build error.

Change-Id: Iec4942f6b3849ae3ec340b47940e3923d260974f
Closes-Bug: #1494553
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/50/222950/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: uses the following two example architectures: Three-node architecture with OpenStack Networking (neutron) ----------------------------------------------------------- This example uses a three-note architecture with OpenStack Networking (neutron) and optional nodes for Block Storage and Object Storage services. The :term:`controller node <cloud controller node>` runs the Identity service, Image Service, management portions of Compute and Networking, Networking plug-in, and the dashboard. It also includes supporting services such as an SQL database, :term:`message queue`, and :term:`Network Time Protocol (NTP)`. Optionally, the controller node runs portions of Block Storage, Object Storage, Orchestration, Telemetry, Database, and Data processing services. These components provide additional features for your environment. The network node runs the Networking plug-in and several agents that provision tenant networks and provide switching, routing, :term:`NAT<Network Address Translation (NAT)>`, and :term:`DHCP` services. This node also handles external (internet) connectivity for tenant virtual machine instances. The :term:`compute node` runs the :term:`hypervisor` portion of Compute that operates :term:`tenant` :term:`virtual machines <virtual machine (VM)>` or instances. By default, Compute uses :term:`KVM <kernel-based VM (KVM)>` as the :term:`hypervisor`. The compute node also runs the Networking plug-in and an agent that connect tenant networks to instances and provide firewalling (:term:`security groups <security group>`) services. You can run more than one compute node. Optionally, the compute node runs a Telemetry agent to collect meters. Also, it can contain a third network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. The optional Block Storage node contains the disks that the Block Storage service provisions for tenant virtual machine instances. You can run more than one of these nodes. Optionally, the Block Storage node runs a Telemetry agent to collect meters. Also, it can contain a second network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. The optional Object Storage nodes contain the disks that the Object Storage service uses for storing accounts, containers, and objects. You can run more than two of these nodes. However, the minimal architecture example requires two nodes. Optionally, these nodes can contain a second network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. .. note:: When you implement this architecture, skip the section :doc:`networking-nova`. Optional services might require additional nodes or additional resources on existing nodes.Two-node architecture with legacy networking (nova-network) ----------------------------------------------------------- This example uses a two-node architecture with legacy networking (nove-network) and optional nodes for Block Storage and Object Storage services. The :term:`controller node <cloud controller node>` runs the Identity service, Image service, management portion of Compute, and the dashboard. It also includes supporting services such as an SQL database, :term:`message queue`, and :term:`Network Time Protocol (NTP)`. Optionally, the controller node runs portions of Block Storage, Object Storage, Orchestration, Telemetry, Database, and Data processing services. These components provide additional features for your environment. The :term:`compute node` runs the :term:`hypervisor` portion of Compute that operates :term:`tenant` :term:`virtual machines <virtual machine (VM)>` or instances. By default, Compute uses :term:`KVM <kernel-based VM (KVM)>` as the :term:`hypervisor`. Compute also provisions tenant networks and provides firewalling (:term:`security groups <security group>`) services. You can run more than one compute node. Optionally, the compute node runs a Telemetry agent to collect meters. Also, it can contain a third network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. The optional Block Storage node contains the disks that the Block Storage service provisions for tenant virtual machine instances. You can run more than one of these nodes. Optionally, the Block Storage node runs a Telemetry agent to collect meters. Also, it can contain a second network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. The optional Object Storage nodes contain the disks that the Object Storage service uses for storing accounts, containers, and objects. You can run more than two of these nodes. However, the minimal architecture example requires two nodes. Optionally, these nodes can contain a second network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. .. note:: When you implement this architecture, skip the section :doc:`networking-neutron`. To use optional services, you might need to build additional nodes.

Optionally, these nodes can contain a second network interface on a separate storage network to improve performance of storage services. .. note:: When you implement this architecture, skip the section :doc:`networking-neutron`. To use optional services, you might need to build additional nodes.

commit_message:
[security-guide] Ephemeral encryption setup

The Data Encryption section in the OpenStack security guide needs
some info added to describe how to enable ephemeral disk encryption.
Change-Id: I58766ee7481ee9cbba3cd2a960adcaf4809d8ee0
Closes-Bug: #1467551
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/56/218956/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - The compute configuration, nova.conf, has the following default parameters within the [ephemeral_storage_encryption] section - cipher = aes-xts-plain64 - This field sets the cipher and mode used to encrypt ephemeral storage. Aes-xts is recommended by NIST specifically for disk storage.* Available ciphers depend on kernel support. At the command line, type 'cyrptsetup benchmark' to determine the available options (and see benchmark results), or go to /proc/crypto - enabled = false - To use ephemeral disk encryption, set enabled = true - key_size = 512 - Using the recommended 512-bit setting, the underlying XTS key size is only 256-bit.* Therefore, selecting a key size less than the 512-bit default is not recommended
deleted_lines: - Compute configuration enables encryption and specifies encryption parameters such as algorithm and key size

commit_message:
Revert "Pecan WSGI: prevent plugins from opening AMQP connections"

This reverts commit 2ba2456f9dae2a4cf30804a562c08832c24b6231
because it has a conflict with upstream commit
9f6bd17703b7286be9e7d439d15f4dec2774e13a. We need to merge
master into pecan with this reverted and then revert the revert
and resolve the conflict there so we don't have any conflict
resolutions in merge commits.

Change-Id: I22388de076cbd90da33502249e101749e019e0cb

commit_message:
Remove DictMatches custom matcher from unit tests

On Py27 assertDictEqual handles nested dictionaries just fine.

Change-Id: I0695a1249a3c4153ba4cc49405640a3e09a2af04
Closes-Bug: #1496552

deleted_lines: from ironic.tests import matchers self.assertThat(image_meta, matchers.DictMatches(expected)) self.assertThat(image_metas[0], matchers.DictMatches(expected)) self.assertThat(actual, matchers.DictMatches(expected)) self.assertThat(meta, matchers.DictMatches(expected)) self.assertThat(meta, matchers.DictMatches(expected))

commit_message:
VPNaaS Scenario tests using Rally

Introducing VPNaaS scenario tests using Rally. This patch contains
rally-jobs/plugins/vpn_utils.py file that holds a few utility
functions that will be used by the actual test files.

Change-Id: I01aa18be580211f1013a2203d69dc8bd2200c514

subject: Extend the state machine spec to cover DEPLOYWAIT and abort
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 10:10:56.000000000', 'files': ['specs/kilo-implemented/new-ironic-state-machine.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/commit/fca728a65b6361b69ee6666aabf94e1cfa038241', 'message': 'Extend the state machine spec to cover DEPLOYWAIT and abort

This patches extend the state machine spec to cover the DEPLOYWAIT state
that was missing and also to talk abort "abort" verb that is being
introduced to the CLEANWAIT state.

The API verb was also corrected, in the API the verb to delete an
instance is "deleted" (for historical reasons) and not "delete".

Change-Id: Id3f7d39027bff43a336cfcdeaf6ba18d6463be51
'}]
commit_message:
Extend the state machine spec to cover DEPLOYWAIT and abort

This patches extend the state machine spec to cover the DEPLOYWAIT state
that was missing and also to talk abort "abort" verb that is being
introduced to the CLEANWAIT state.

The API verb was also corrected, in the API the verb to delete an
instance is "deleted" (for historical reasons) and not "delete".

Change-Id: Id3f7d39027bff43a336cfcdeaf6ba18d6463be51
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/08/224008/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The cleaning process of a node in CLEANWAIT can be interrupted via the ``abort`` API call. DEPLOYWAIT Just like the DEPLOYING state, the nodes in DEPLOYWAIT are being deployed. The difference is that in DEPLOYWAIT the conductor is waiting for the ramdisk to boot or execute parts of the deployment which needs to run in-band on the node (for example, installing the bootloader, writing the image to the disk when iSCSI is not used, etc...). The deployment of a node in DEPLOYWAIT provision state can be interrupted via the ``deleted`` API call. | deleted | ACTIVE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE || deleted | RESCUE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE || deleted | DEPLOYWAIT | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE | | | | CLEANING -> CLEANED | | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+ | abort | CLEANWAIT | (none) | CLEANFAIL | +-----------+--------------+--------------------------+-----------+
deleted_lines: | delete | ACTIVE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE || delete | RESCUE | DELETING -> DELETED -> | AVAILABLE |

commit_message:
Show reserved status for a fixed_ip if available

Commit 8886590f30daf736ae30a95b3e4a77cb586d4f02 adds the v2.4
microversion to nova so that we can get back the reserved value of a
fixed IP.

This change adds support to novaclient to display the reserved status
from the fixed_ip resource if it's available in the response.

Related blueprint show-reserved-status-in-os-fixed-ips-api

Change-Id: Idf3df1728ba87006d1b0f82a1c01712202670e0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/46/190346/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fields = ['address', 'cidr', 'hostname', 'host'] # NOTE(mriedem): The v2.4 microversion adds the reserved boolean to the # fixed_ip response, so it won't be there if using < v2.4. if hasattr(result, 'reserved'): fields.append('reserved') utils.print_list([result], fields)

commit_message:
VMware: create method for getting datacenter from datastore

The method previously defined in vmops was factored out to be a
utility method. This is to enable us to use this in additional
classes.

Change-Id: Ia8139a7d0cc95fb3333015470556103914db3cf0
Related-Bug: #1428645

subject: Pass block_device_info when delete an encrypted lvm
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 06:59:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f8abce9cebc8488135b1020922289e692780ad5c', 'message': "Pass block_device_info when delete an encrypted lvm

This is a regression bug, in Ifb20655c32896b640672917e3840add81b136780,
we made get_instance_disk_info() conservative, it requires block_device_info
if disk_type is `block`.

But currently, in _detach_encrypted_volumes, we don't pass bdi when calling
get_instance_disk_info, so it returns nothing, and nova doesn't delete the
encryptor volume, and failed to delete the lvm when deleting instance.

Co-Authored-By: LisaLi <xiaoyan.li@intel.com>
Closes-Bug: #1486880
Change-Id: Ibc7e4a3c0e98dc70f7bd30d789069ba27eec7d76
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-26 02:42:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2daa604ce61845c7100732bb835bf1b350c1bff6', 'message': "Pass block_device_info when delete an encrypted lvm

This is a regression bug, in Ifb20655c32896b640672917e3840add81b136780,
we made get_instance_disk_info() conservative, it requires block_device_info
if disk_type is `block`.

But currently, in _detach_encrypted_volumes, we don't pass bdi when calling
get_instance_disk_info, so it returns nothing, and nova doesn't delete the
encryptor volume, and failed to delete the lvm when deleting instance.

Co-Authored-By: LisaLi <xiaoyan.li@intel.com>
Closes-Bug: #1486880
Change-Id: Ibc7e4a3c0e98dc70f7bd30d789069ba27eec7d76

commit_message:
Pass block_device_info when delete an encrypted lvm

This is a regression bug, in Ifb20655c32896b640672917e3840add81b136780,
we made get_instance_disk_info() conservative, it requires block_device_info
if disk_type is `block`.

But currently, in _detach_encrypted_volumes, we don't pass bdi when calling
get_instance_disk_info, so it returns nothing, and nova doesn't delete the
encryptor volume, and failed to delete the lvm when deleting instance.

Co-Authored-By: LisaLi <xiaoyan.li@intel.com>
Closes-Bug: #1486880
Change-Id: Ibc7e4a3c0e98dc70f7bd30d789069ba27eec7d76

commit_message:
Fix string formatting in api/metadata/vendordata_json.py

The string format should be "%(logprefix)s", add the missing "s" in one
case.

The strings currently do not include a space after the "s" which
confuses translators.  Add the space and remove it from logprefix.

Change-Id: I6b3113e184c9c3cee1e2ebe448655c7488efb61b
Closes-Bug: #1496273

commit_message:
Make query to quota usage table order preserved

Currently, the query to quota usage table is not order
preserved. This might cause deadlock in large-scale
deployment: different calls may lock rows in different
order, and deadlock will happen.

This patch adds order_by to the query and make the query
to the table order preserved.

Change-Id: I98f6d7c3141349326c43cb32adcc1e6485ad53a6
Closes-bug: #1485408

commit_message:
ovs: don't use ARP responder for IPv6 addresses

ARP does not support IPv6 addresses, so when we try to apply the flow, it
fails, with all other flows deferred for the same transaction. It results in
random flow breakages, depending on the order of the bad flow in the
transaction.

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/test_ovs_neutron_agent.py

Change-Id: I0ecf167653e5a7d0916e091e05050406a026a1e2
Co-Authored-By: Thomas Carroll <Thomas.Carroll@pnnl.gov>
Closes-Bug: #1477253
(cherry picked from commit a19e64c9d95781982d28113c667dbc90d0ea11eb)

subject: Broadcast service port's arp in DVR
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-11 01:31:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/99ab1ecd3654ddd662de97d0b3d5c6b1a4b458f2', 'message': "Broadcast service port's arp in DVR

When creating VMs, DVR router will broadcast VM's arp details to all the
l3 agents hosting it. that enable dvr can forwarding networking traffic
in link layer, but when the port is attached to the service liking
lbaas, their arp will not be broadcast, so the dvr do not know its mac,
and will cause that vms in other subnet can not reach the service port
through the dvr router.

Change-Id: Ia78a35f39981d6659fc220e02fb10917bda74e04
Closes-Bug: #1481613

commit_message:
Broadcast service port's arp in DVR

When creating VMs, the DVR router will broadcast VM's arp details to all
the l3 agents hosting it. That can enable DVR to forward networking traffic
in link layer, but when the port is attached to a service like lbaas,
its arp will not be broadcast, since DVR does not know the port's mac,
it will prevent VMs in other subnets from reaching the service port.

Change-Id: Ia78a35f39981d6659fc220e02fb10917bda74e04
Closes-Bug: #1481613
(cherry picked from commit 85ebf88afa04986cd0e5d65f20c9f286820d87a5)

commit_message:
Attaching enhancement for EMC VNX driver

Remove the lun list command after adding the lun into a storage
group. This could improve the performance of initialize connection.

Change-Id: Id49725f50cd0e7600feb2ffc98a5b1ef14bc531c
Closes-Bug: #1495806

commit_message:
libvirt: use guest as parameter for get serial ports

This is a preparation patch for enabling live migration with
serial console, which will introduce a new user of
get_serial_ports_for_guest().

Move the get_guest call to the caller of
get_serial_ports_for_guest() to avoid the generation of an
exception in a generator.

Change-Id: Ice0a81e576313732d742926c4c05d8251e6ca6d5

subject: Clarify max_local_block_devices config option usage

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-04 01:45:57.000000000', 'files': ['nova/compute/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6ef48140999e6fe2d23e6e0c61dfdd41e07359e9', 'message': 'Clarify max_local_block_devices config option usage

commit_message:
Clarify max_local_block_devices config option usage

The previous wording for the max_local_block_devices config option made
it sound like if you set it to 0 that you could restrict to only booting
instances from volumes, which is not the case - but is apparently
something that some operators want (this came up in the related bug and
in IRC).

This updates the help text with a description that ndipanov put in the
bug report which makes the 0 case more clear.

Co-Authored-By: Nikola Dipanov <ndipanov@redhat.com>

Related-Bug: #1436314

Change-Id: I01a9e2f193b50285966690efd771da432a7ad40c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/75/220375/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'A negative number means unlimited. Setting ' 'max_local_block_devices to 0 means that any request that ' 'attempts to create a local disk will fail. This option ' 'is meant to limit the number of local discs (so root ' 'local disc that is the result of --image being used, and ' 'any other ephemeral and swap disks). 0 does not mean ' 'that images will be automatically converted to volumes ' 'and boot instances from volumes - it just means that all ' 'requests that attempt to create a local disk will fail.'),
deleted_lines: 'Setting this to 0 means nova will allow only ' 'boot from volume. A negative number means unlimited.'),

commit_message:
do not recreate main queue listeners on partitioning

when we have workload partitioning enabled, we kill and recreate
the main queue listeners whenever an agent is added or dropped.
this isn't necessary and also adds significant overhead to
rebalancing logic. this patch changes it to just reconfigure
pipeline queues.

Change-Id: I81953239f2dd1fa610762f01a7a17653242db53e
Closes-Bug: #1496442

commit_message:
Remove SQL GET request from UpdateAmphoraComputeId

"UpdateAmphoraComputeId" task actually return an object and perform
a SQL request not used by any taskflow.
"UpdateAmphoraComputeId" task usage in amphora_flows doesn't
provides anything. Hence SQL request and return value can be avoided.

Change-Id: I93eca3193435fd59fc2d73fc1d820ae51fde3e03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/80/224480/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Added a whitelist for restricting the StatsD metrics
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-28 00:02:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-thresh/commit/abecb6415412437e5bfe031b21c6d7ef101a681a', 'message': '[WIP] Added a whitelist for restricting the StatsD metrics

A whitelist and metric map for the metrics that are
sent by Storm / Threshold Engine to the Monasca
StatsD agent/daemon.

=======

/etc/monasca/thresh-config.yml

```
statsdConfig:
  host: localhost
  port: 8125
  debugmetrics: true
  dimensions: !!map
    service : monitoring
    component : storm
  metricmap: !!map
    someMetricName : someNewMetricName
  whitelist: !!seq
    - someMetricName
```

host: IP or host where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD is running that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

port: UDP port number where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD daemon that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

prefix: This string will be prefixed to the internal metric

dimensions: A map of key/value pairs that will be passed along as dimensions for each metric

whitelist: A list of metrics in the native name that Storm presents

metricmap: A mapping from the native Storm metric name to a user defined name.  The user
           defined name is what will appear in the Monasca data store.  If there is no
           mapping present and it is listed in the whitelist then it will be published
           with the native name.

Change-Id: I7bcefd03d02714ac42efd9b2d9cadb77907fa17e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-29 18:59:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-thresh/commit/209a01c96db9ae6855bab90e152a8318efa455da', 'message': 'Added a whitelist for restricting the StatsD metrics

A whitelist and metric map for the metrics that are
sent by Storm / Threshold Engine to the Monasca
StatsD agent/daemon.

=======

/etc/monasca/thresh-config.yml

```
statsdConfig:
  host: localhost
  port: 8125
  debugmetrics: true
  dimensions: !!map
    service : monitoring
    component : storm
  whitelist: !!seq
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick
    - filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events
    - filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default
    - thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default
    - thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events
    - system.memory_heap.committedBytes
    - system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes
    - system.newWorkerEvent
    - system.startTimeSecs
    - system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs
  metricmap: !!map
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream :
      monasca.storm.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default :
      monasca.storm.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick :
      monasca.storm.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick
    filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events :
      monasca.storm.filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events
    filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default :
      monasca.storm.filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default
    thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default :
      monasca.storm.thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default
    thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events :
      monasca.storm.thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events
    system.memory_heap.committedBytes :
      monasca.storm.system.memory_heap.committedBytes
    system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes :
      monasca.storm.system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes
    system.newWorkerEvent :
      monasca.storm.system.newWorkerEvent
    system.startTimeSecs :
      monasca.storm.system.startTimeSecs
    system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs :
      monasca.storm.system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs
```

host: IP or host where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD is running that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

port: UDP port number where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD daemon that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

prefix: This string will be prefixed to the internal metric

dimensions: A map of key/value pairs that will be passed along as dimensions for each metric

whitelist: A list of metrics in the native name that Storm presents

metricmap: A mapping from the native Storm metric name to a user defined name.  The user
           defined name is what will appear in the Monasca data store.  If there is no
           mapping present and it is listed in the whitelist then it will be published
           with the native name. The 12 metrics whitelisted/mapped above correspond to the
           monasca health dashboard we that is predefined in grafana.
           github.com/hpcloud-mon/grafana/src/app/dashboards/monasca.json

Change-Id: I7bcefd03d02714ac42efd9b2d9cadb77907fa17e

commit_message:
Added a whitelist for restricting the StatsD metrics

A whitelist and metric map for the metrics that are
sent by Storm / Threshold Engine to the Monasca
StatsD agent/daemon.

Also relates to:
  https://github.com/hpcloud-mon/ansible-monasca-thresh/pull/14

=======

/etc/monasca/thresh-config.yml

```
statsdConfig:
  host: localhost
  port: 8125
  debugmetrics: false
  dimensions: !!map
    service : monitoring
    component : storm
  whitelist: !!seq
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default
    - aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick
    - filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events
    - filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default
    - thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default
    - thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events
    - system.memory_heap.committedBytes
    - system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes
    - system.newWorkerEvent
    - system.startTimeSecs
    - system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs
  metricmap: !!map
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream :
      monasca_threshold.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_alarm-creation-stream
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default :
      monasca_threshold.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.filtering-bolt_default
    aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick :
      monasca_threshold.aggregation-bolt.execute-count.system_tick
    filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events :
      monasca_threshold.filtering-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_metric-alarm-events
    filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default :
      monasca_threshold.filtering-bolt.execute-count.metrics-spout_default
    thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default :
      monasca_threshold.thresholding-bolt.execute-count.aggregation-bolt_default
    thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events :
      monasca_threshold.thresholding-bolt.execute-count.event-bolt_alarm-definition-events
    system.memory_heap.committedBytes :
      monasca_threshold.system.memory_heap.committedBytes
    system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes :
      monasca_threshold.system.memory_nonHeap.committedBytes
    system.newWorkerEvent :
      monasca_threshold.system.newWorkerEvent
    system.startTimeSecs :
      monasca_threshold.system.startTimeSecs
    system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs :
      monasca_threshold.system.GC_ConcurrentMarkSweep.timeMs
```

host: IP or host where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD is running that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

port: UDP port number where the Monasca Agent running a StatsD daemon that will consume
      the metrics produced by Storm / Threshold Engine

dimensions: A map of key/value pairs that will be passed along as dimensions for each metric

whitelist: A list of metrics in the native name that Storm presents

metricmap: A mapping from the native Storm metric name to a user defined name.  The user
           defined name is what will appear in the Monasca data store.  If there is no
           mapping present and it is listed in the whitelist then it will be published
           with the native name. The 12 metrics whitelisted/mapped above correspond to the
           monasca health dashboard which is defined in grafana.

           https://github.com/hpcloud-mon/grafana/blob/master/src/app/dashboards/monasca.json

Change-Id: I7bcefd03d02714ac42efd9b2d9cadb77907fa17e

added_lines: import java.lang.String;import java.util.*;import java.util.HashMap; public static final String STATSD_METRICMAP = "metrics.statsd.metricmap"; public static final String STATSD_WHITELIST = "metrics.statsd.whitelist"; public static final String STATSD_DEBUGMETRICS = "metrics.statsd.debugmetrics"; List<String> whitelist = new ArrayList<String>(); Map<String, String> metricmap; Boolean debugMetrics = false; "topologyName ({}), clean(topologyName) ({})", new Object[] { topologyName, clean(topologyName) }); reportUOM(metric.name, metric.value); public Metric(String name, Double value) { return "Metric [name=" + name + ", value=" + value + "]"; res.add(new Metric(sb.toString(), ((Number) p.value).doubleValue())); res.add(new Metric(sb.toString(), ((Number) subValue).doubleValue())); public void report(String s) { if (udpclient != null) { logger.debug("reporting: {}", s); udpclient.send(s); private void reportUOM(String s, Double number) { String uom = null; StringBuilder results = new StringBuilder(); if (whitelist.contains(s)) { if (metricmap.containsKey(s)) { uom = metricmap.get(s); } // send the unmapped uom as the same name storm calls it else { uom = s; } } if (debugMetrics) { logger.info(", StormMetricName, {}, uom, {}, val, {}", new Object[] { s, metricmap.get(s), number}); } if (uom != null && !uom.isEmpty()) { results = results.append(uom).append(":") .append(String.valueOf(number)).append("|c").append(statsdDimensions); report(results.toString()); } }
deleted_lines: public static final String STATSD_PREFIX = "metrics.statsd.prefix"; String statsdPrefix = "monasca.storm."; "statsdPrefix ({}), topologyName ({}), clean(topologyName) ({})", new Object[] { statsdPrefix, topologyName, clean(topologyName) }); if (conf.containsKey(STATSD_PREFIX)) { statsdPrefix = (String) conf.get(STATSD_PREFIX); if (!statsdPrefix.endsWith(".")) { statsdPrefix += "."; } } report(metric.name, metric.value, metric.dimensions); String dimensions; public Metric(String name, Double value, String dimensions) { this.dimensions = dimensions; if (!dimensions.equals(other.dimensions)) return false; return "Metric [name=" + name + ", value=" + value + ", dimensions=" + dimensions + "]"; res.add(new Metric(sb.toString(), ((Number) p.value).doubleValue(), statsdDimensions)); res.add(new Metric(sb.toString(), ((Number) subValue).doubleValue(), statsdDimensions)); public void report(String s, Double number, String dimensions) { if (udpclient != null) { StringBuilder statsdMessage = new StringBuilder().append(statsdPrefix) .append(s).append(":").append(String.valueOf(number)).append("|c") .append(statsdDimensions); logger.debug("reporting: {}={}{}", s, number, dimensions); udpclient.send(statsdMessage.toString());

commit_message:
Adding an OSSN for bug 1457551 - django session store DoS

A bug in Django that affects versions of Horizon pre-Kilo allows
an attacker to potentially DoS Horizon by filling the session
store database.

Closes-Bug #1457551
Change-Id: I2d151992a9da947ed1a70e15619faaeece943da7
Co-Authored-By: Michael Xin <michael.xin@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/85/219885/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Potential Denial of Service in Horizon login --- ### Summary ### Horizon uses the python based Django web framework. Older versions of this framework allow an unauthorized user to fill up the session store database causing a Horizon denial of service. A fix for Django is available but works only with Kilo and later versions of Horizon. ### Affected Services / Software ### Horizon, Django, Essex, Folsom, Grizzly, Havana, Icehouse, Juno ### Discussion ### Django will record the session ID of web requests even when the request is from an unauthorized user. This allows an attacker to populate the session store database with invalid session information, potentially causing a denial of service condition by filling the database with useless session information. ### Recommended Actions ### The django developers have released a fix for this issue which is included in software versions 1.4.21, 1.7.9 and 1.8.3. Horizon administrators should ensure that they are using an up to date version of Django to avoid being affected by this vulnerability. Versions of Horizon prior to Kilo cannot run with the fixed version of Django. Administrators can test if their deployment is affected by attempting to inject invalid sessions into the session store database using the following script and then querying the session store database to check if multiple 'aaaaa' session ID's were recorded. ---- begin example ---- for i in {1..100} do curl -b "sessionid=aaaaa;" http://HORIZON__IP/auth/login/ &> /dev/null done' ---- end example ---- If possible, affected users should upgrade to the Kilo or newer release of Horizon, allowing them to use the fixed version of Django. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0054 Django fix : https://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2015/jul/08/security-releases/ Django CVE : CVE-2015-5143 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1457551 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

commit_message:
Add OSSN-0058

Cinder LVMISCIDriver allows possible unauthenticated mounting of volumes

Change-Id: I15de98bdad06753b5bf68ebb7f635da698df29e7
Closes-Bug: 1329214
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/39/219939/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Cinder LVMISCIDriver allows possible unauthenticated mounting of volumes --- ### Summary ### When using the LVMISCSIDriver with Cinder, the credentials for CHAP authentication are not formatted correctly in the tgtadm configuration file. This leads to a condition where an operator will expect that volumes can only be mounted with the authentication credentials when, in fact, they can be mounted without the credentials. ### Affected Services / Software ### Cinder, Icehouse ### Discussion ### When requesting that LVMISCSIDriver based volumes use the CHAP authentication protocol, Cinder will add the credentials for authentication to the configuration file for the `tgtadm` application. In pre-Juno versions of Cinder the key name for these credentials is incorrect. This incorrect key name will cause `tgtadm` to not properly parse those credentials. With incorrect credentials in place, `tgtadm` will fail to authenticate volume mounting when requested by Cinder. The failed setting of credentials through the configuration file will also allow unauthenticated access to these volumes. This can allow instances on the same network as the volumes to mount them without providing the credentials to the `tgtadm` application. This behavior can be confirmed by displaying the accounts associated with a volume. For volumes which have authentication enabled, you will see an account listed the the output of the `tgtadm` application. The account names created by Cinder will be randomly generated and will appear as 20 character strings. To print the information for volumes the following command can be run on nodes with attached volumes: # tgtadm --lld iscsi --op show --mode target User names will be found in the `Account information:` section. ### Recommended Actions ### If possible, Cinder should be updated to the stable Juno release. If this is not an option, then restricting access to port 3260 will prevent iscsi traffic to affected nodes. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0058 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1329214 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

commit_message:
Fix nova bash-completion needs authentication

  CLI-Reference generator requires
   (openstack-doc-tools/bin/doc-tools-update-cli-reference)
  that command line help and bash-completion running without authentication.

  For this purpose, remove authentication check in command and its test.
    Fix nova bash-completion works without authentication.
    Fix nova bash-completion test without setting authentication infomation.

  Define skip_auth for descriminate "nova bash-completion" and do_help.

Change-Id: Ic1a7f84b1b9cb7e8be6721c1b8096f49e9e9ab33
Closes-Bug: #1495424

commit_message:
Scrub Images in Parallel

This change proposal introduces a way for the scrubber to scrub
images in parallel when delayed delete is enabled.

Change-Id: Ic72bf2b82282b4f56fc6769de4bfacb54aa31253
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/84/222284/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Scrub Images in Parallel ======================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/scrub-images-in-parallel This change proposal introduces a way for the scrubber to scrub images in parallel when delayed delete is enabled. Problem description =================== As of today, when delayed delete is enabled, images are being scrubbed serially while the image locations, if multiple, are being scrubbed in parallel. For the general case, this may not achieve much performance gain as the number of images is likely to be more than the number of image locations per image. Consequently, the scrubber can fall behind when the number of pending_delete images increase. Proposed change =============== This change will attempt to parallelize image scrubbing while leaving image locations to be scrubbed serially. A new config option would be introduced to offer the flexibility to choose between serial or parallel scrubbing. Also, using this config option, one can regulate the degree of parallelism to a desired level. Alternatives ------------ - One can run multiple scrubbers to keep up with the increase in pending_delete images. However, in that case, scrubbers may race as they all get the same set of images from the registry. This may not be a bad option if one can ignore all the errors in the logs. Nevertheless, scrubbing images serially is still inefficient. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ When using parallel scrubbing one must take into account any rate-limits on the backend store. Depending on extent of parallelism desired, scrubber may hit the rate-limits of the backend store and may eventually slowdown or fail. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hemanth-makkapati Other contributors: jesse-j-cook Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar Other reviewer(s): flaper87 brian-rosmaita Work Items ---------- - Use eventlet to parallelize image scrubbing - Monkey-patch required modules for eventlet - Test on devstack Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== The new configuration option would require documentation. References ========== None

subject: Fix alternating status when status is "None"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 02:09:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/5c77194c1e205579eb5e3240d3dafbe175a19a86', 'message': 'Fix alternating status when status is "None"

- Instance status would still alternate because the status
would be None and the guest agent heartbeat would set the
status to ACTIVE before the prepare would get called.
- Fix was to check if self.status is None when and force
is False. This will ensure the heartbeat will be skipped.
- Added force=True to begin_install because we always want
to set the status to BUILDING when prepare is started.
- Added unit test to cover new None case.

Change-Id: Ia7d8ef3a4973b990c695262b21fb5d36088efb1b
Closes-Bug: 1482795
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-16 21:56:15.000000000', 'files': ['trove/tests/unittests/guestagent/test_dbaas.py', 'trove/guestagent/datastore/service.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/d200e6d39f35ff81f643fc1c7be779fb48cc3e42', 'message': 'Fix alternating status when status is "None"

- Instance status would still alternate because the status
would be None and the guest agent heartbeat would set the
status to ACTIVE before the prepare would get called.
- Added check if self.status is None when and force
is False. This will ensure the heartbeat will be skipped.
- Added SHUTDOWN status as a FORCE heartbeat status. This
ensures resize_instance will work.
- Added force=True to begin_install because we always want
to set the status to BUILDING when prepare is started.
- Added unit test to cover new None case.

Change-Id: Ia7d8ef3a4973b990c695262b21fb5d36088efb1b

commit_message:
Fix alternating status when status is "None"

- Instance status would still alternate because the status
would be None and the guest agent heartbeat would set the
status to ACTIVE before the prepare would get called.
- Added check if self.status is None when and force
is False. This will ensure the heartbeat will be skipped.
- Added SHUTDOWN status as a FORCE heartbeat status. This
ensures resize_instance will work.
- Added force=True to begin_install because we always want
to set the status to BUILDING when prepare is started.
- Added unit test to cover new None case.

Change-Id: Ia7d8ef3a4973b990c695262b21fb5d36088efb1b
Closes-Bug: 1482795

commit_message:
Rename 'fields' to '_source'

Renames the search 'fields' attribute to '_source' to match the
elasticsearch (and python-elasticsearch) APIs. Refactors the ES
gateway a bit to pass kwargs through since there was some default
argument translation that will get out of hand.

Change-Id: I5d5d3f3cb30e0441dea86b2fe707825966288fba
Closes-Bug: #1493586

commit_message:
Localization framework in neutron is not working correctly

Currently in Stable/Juno only neutron-log-info.po file is present for
neutron code but the code is using neutron as domain.
Also locale directory to use is being fetched from environment
which is not set, hence locale files are not located using
gettext utility successfully.
Closes-Bug: #1441982

Change-Id: If858ac4840a6e921b0c0d9fdc9bdee3827c0df22

commit_message:
Refactor the _get_external_device_interface_name method

Currently this method does two things. It returns the
external interface name as its name indicates and
creates some interfaces in the case of the dvr mode.
This patch split these two things into two methods and
refactor a bit the code according to this change.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/l3/agent.py
	neutron/tests/unit/test_l3_agent.py

(cherry-picked from 6e5762be5b3324f1cf0e52f2680455d760bcc3ea)
Related-Bug: #1375994
Change-Id: I7dc2c03457cbb209c84584c2badffd12048e9617

commit_message:
Initialize dist_fip_count after agent restart

Runtime router variable dist_fip_count has been
used to keep track of FIPs for DVR routers.
This variable is not re-initialized correctly on
agent restart and can get stale from other errors
which cause problems with namespace and port cleanup.

This patch will initialize the ri.dist_fip_count
once in process_router for dvr routers only.  This
method was selected instead of the _router_added or
_router_removed path because it is the one central
entry point for rotuer add, delete, and update.

The object self.agent_gateway_port also needs to be
properly handled after an agent restart and this
patch will handle that as well.

When needed, the system will be read via system
calls to determine the state of namespaces and ports
since the variables cannot be relied on.
System calls will be kept to a minimum to reduce
and possible performance hits.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/l3/agent.py
	neutron/agent/l3/dvr.py
	neutron/services/vpn/device_drivers/__init__.py
	neutron/tests/unit/test_l3_agent.py

(cherry-picked from ee4bae211309e0f1fcee5565ddd2379997e1de13)
Change-Id: Iae5ebf5249f8e16ab57df78e042293ca2855ddf1
Closes-bug: #1367039

commit_message:
Unregister some configuration options after test

Configuraiton opitons in KSM's testcase is not registered by
oslo_config.fixture.Config, so it will no be unregistered after
testcases, this requires us to clean these options by ourselves.

In this patch, we clean these options which has been registered
more than one times with different value since they will cause
DuplicateOptError exceptions.

Co-Authored-By: Lin Hua Cheng <os.lcheng@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I5f2a348460d44b8e24cdaaeaebe66b510e7a6255
Closes-Bug: #1494327
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/19/222919/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.addCleanup(self.clean_conf_outof_fixture) def clean_conf_outof_fixture(self): opts = set() # NOTE(davechen): Since other configuration options such as # 'auth_plugin', 'auth_url' are referenced in lot of testcases # defaultly, these configuration options cannot be cleaned easily. password_plugin_conf = ['user_id', 'username', 'password'] group_name = 'keystone_authtoken' for group in self.cfg.conf._groups.keys(): if group != group_name: continue for conf in password_plugin_conf: info = self.cfg.conf._groups[group]._opts.get(conf) if info: opts.add(info['opt']) self.cfg.conf.unregister_opts(opts, group=group_name)

commit_message:
Replace urllib.unquote with urllib.parse.unquote

This patch replaces urllib.unquote with urllib.parse.unquote
in the vmdk driver.

Commit d08c7ffe52e3ee211e425c363200998704726e58 replaced
urllib and urllib2 with six.moves.urllib and changed urllib.
unquote to urllib.parse.unquote but missed one call site
in the vmdk driver since the code which introduced it was
under review at the same time. Due to this, if we set an
optional parameter 'vmware_cluster_name', the driver init
will fail with AttributeError.

This patch also adds a unit test which would have caught
this error during gate check.

Change-Id: I310456f5d677c6e100a91efc6228c533cb5bf208
Closes-Bug: #1488916
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/89/217089/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
ML2: Move repeated calls to set constants out of delete_port to init

There is no reason to make these 2 calls inside of delete_port each time.
This occurs a lot thus I've moved them to be set once at __init__.
Change-Id: I733202d06f645329c43a986abdea3c3e6b10777b

commit_message:
JSCS Cleanup - use DI in launch instance model

Per the JP style guide, implements getter syntax rather than declaring a
variable for the module, and implements DI for the service as well.

Change-Id: I5a29dafb4fc4a1b5f3c4bee2b7ff73e7a6151eee
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup

} delete finalSpec.key_pair; } // Security Groups function onGetSecurityGroups(data) { model.securityGroups.length = 0; push.apply(model.securityGroups, data.data.items); // set initial default if (model.newInstanceSpec.security_groups.length === 0 && model.securityGroups.length > 0) { model.securityGroups.forEach(function (securityGroup) { if (securityGroup.name === 'default') { model.newInstanceSpec.security_groups.push(securityGroup); } }); } } function setFinalSpecSecurityGroups(finalSpec) { // pull out the ids from the security groups objects var securityGroupIds = []; finalSpec.security_groups.forEach(function(securityGroup) { if (model.neutronEnabled) { securityGroupIds.push(securityGroup.id); } function isBootableImageType(image) { // This is a blacklist of images that can not be booted. // If the image container type is in the blacklist // The evaluation will result in a 0 or greater index. return NON_BOOTABLE_IMAGE_TYPES.indexOf(image.container_format) < 0; commit_message:
JSCS Cleanup - rename launch instance factory files

Per the JP style guide, renames factory and its spec to use the
.service.js convention. Future change will refactor the factory to use
the getter syntax as well as DI.

Change-Id: Iacd56999e35247ea2d95dc6dd8337a5ea4e8016e
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup
