commit_message:
Rethinking scheduling

Very early concept draft about a DB oriented parallel scheduling.

Change-Id: I5ea7f08f4e4c165b0bfe9094c31c3359c9f746ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/86/170186/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================== Scheduler Rethinking ==================== EARLY DRAFT DO NOT READ IT! NEEDS TO BE REORGANIZED. CONTAINS overlapping concepts, some of them will be deleted. Even I did not fully read back :) 1. Introduction 1.1 Problem - high scheduling latency at high node number, scheduler fetches every node even the obviously wrong ones. - single thread CPU intensive operation on the python side 1.1.1 Problem detailed - Processing the records on python side as openstack does today usually 10 times more expensive than letting the DB to it for you. - When the ordering is just ram size based (typical use case), or it can be based on pre-calculated metric (frequent use case), the DB does not even needs to touch all possible computue_node. 1.1.2 Challenges - Many host parameter represented in a JSON blob, which violates the DB 1NF - Several information MAY not be available in the database - Strange existing model, the problem family cannot be easily identified. 1.1.3 Proposed solution Store additional data (helper table(s)) in the DB which helps in filtering and ordering. Have the filters to help in crafting the right query both when they used without, and with helper table. 1.2 Definitions and terms used in this spec 1.2.1 Availability zone or AZ A group of node which can die at same time. For example.: - Nodes located in the same room can be turned off in case of Fire. - Power, Network, Upgrades,.. NOTE: Hosting the storage and server in the same AZ may have better performance. Scheduler MAY pick AZ when the user did not specified one and the instance is booting from an already existing volume. NOTE: Does not makes sense to allow a compute_node being in multiple AZs. 1.2.2 Host aggregate A group of hosts. NOTE: An aggregate can have key value mete data parameters, which MAY be considered by the scheduler. At the moment the scheduler needs to handle the situation, when the host belongs to multiple aggregates. If a compute_node belongs to multiple aggregate the overlapping parameters frequently joined together with ',' or the minimum value used (overcommit ratios) 1.2.3 Scheduler In our context.: An application component or set of application components which is responsible for distributing requested resource or set of resources among multiple resource providers. 1.2.3.1 Resource (E-R model) A resource is an entity with both quantitative and qualitatively attributes. 1.2.3.1.1 Composed resource Composed resource is an entity which composes other resources. Composed resource has both quantitative and qualitatively attributes. NOTE: A composed resource can have attributes which is not derived from the composed resources. 1.2.3.2 Resource type A set of resources which can be described with same set of attribute types. 1.2.3.3 Resources provider Provides one or more type of resources. Example types: Compute , memory, storage, pci device 1.2.3.3.1 coupled resource provider Provides a resources type which implicitly leads to other resource provisioning. For Example: A hyper-visor instance consumes both cpu and memory resources. 1.2.3.4 coupled resource request An all-or-nothing resource request for a set of resources (one or more), be specifying exact quantitative and qualitatively attributes. 1.2.3 Resource claim The process when the scheduler does the required operations to reserve the resources for a (coupled) resource request. 1.2.4 pick The operation when the scheduler decides to use a given host, Not the decision process itself, the act when it attempts to claim the resource. NOTE: The scheduler MAY decide to use more (resource provider) compute_host at the same time. 1.2.5 boot The API request for VM(s) spawning . User boot request the end user requesting for boot boot request th internally requests a boot on a specific hypervisor. Usually it can be considered as coupled resource request. 1.2.6 spawning The process when the compute node starts utilising the resources, and makes it available for the requester. 1.2.7 Flavor, InstanceType A predefined instance attributes, like - Storage size - CPU number - Memory size - Required special devices like GPU Basically it describes a composed resource. 1.2.8 Flavor family A group of flavors/InstanceTypes, same kind of flavors. Which flavors are considered to be member of same type is arbitrary decision, by the operator. A flavor cannot be member of more than one family, A compute host can be related to more family. Two flavor can be considered as same kind for example when they have same memory/vcpu ratio and the same disk type (SSD/Magnetic/None), but they differs in memory size. NOTE: Lets see how the flavors looks like with some public could provider.: http://www.ec2instances.info/ http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/public-pricing#dd-wrap-genv1 http://www.hpcloud.com/pricing Please note one thing here, the memory in the same family was always different, and the other resource size (disk, cpu power) was monotone increased together with the memory. Openstack at the moment does not do anything special with these families, every flavor just exists, the families just exists in the pricing pages and/or in the name of the flavor. 1.2.9 Scheduler filter A software component which can decided which resource provider is not able to provide the requested composed resource (or part of the composed resources set). NOTE: When multiple instances requested in one boot, it can be threated as composed compose resource request. 1.2.9.1 Static filter A filter is static when he is able to decided is the compose resource request can be satisfied, just based on the flavor and the stored attributes of the resource provider(compute_node). 1.2.9.1 Dynamic filter Not static filter. NOTE: Is the filter static or dynamic is a dynamic property, from the resource request the filter MUST be able to answer his type. For example: If the filter just takes action if scheduler hint is passed, it is static filter when no scheduler hint passed, otherwise he can be dynamic. 1.2.8 Statically decidable pick If just by knowing the flavor from the boot parameters you can decided which host can pass or not based on the filters used in the context. 1.2.9 Dynamically decidable pick If the pick is not statically decidable, because it depends on another boot parameters (nic, image properties.. etc) or on the curent weather. 1.2.10 Statically ordered weight If you can decided which host is better just based on the flavor_family and on the compute_host attributes. Note: If you need to consider the currently running instances, stored attributes it is still statically decide able. 1.2.11 Dynamically ordered weight If not statically ordered. For example it depends on the flavor itself not just on the flavor family or on the current weather. NOTE: This type of ordering typically takes more than 0.1 ms, but less than a 1 sec (>100k nodes). 1.2.12 mixed ordering When you select small set (~1000) of host based on statically ordered weight and do the final ordering based on dynamically ordered weight. 1.2.13 Compute host information categories 1.2.13.1 Compute host static attributes The attributes which does not expected or supported to change while the n-cpu is running on the host. For example.: architecture, NUMA topology, Max Memory 1.2.13.2 Compute host controlled attributes The parameters which changes in controlled way. For example.: available vcpu NOTE: CPU/Memory/PCI HotPlug is possible, if it is handled these attributes are controlled. 1.2.13.3 Compute host Dynamic attributes Parameters which changes in a not controlled way. For example.: system load, CPU temperature, system failure 2 Generic concept and options 2.1 Single AZ per compute_node The current model allows to have one node in multiple AZ it should be prevented, It incenses the complexity without a real need. The API SHOULD reject such membership creations. Option: the single AZ can be stored in the services or in compute_nodes table. 2.1.1 Single aggregate per flavor_family The multiple aggregate usage complicates the logic and complexity, of using frequently used parameters. The scheduler should consider the aggregates which is specified in any flavor_group, At scheduling only the one which specified in the flavor_family. Option: Primary compute_nodes group which is an attribute, on the compute_nodes table. NOTE: 2.1 and 2.1.1 can MAY be config option. It is possible to handle it, but it is more expensive. 2.2 Multiple scheduler strategies in the same system Each flavor family can have completely different scheduler. Each scheduler can have multiple scheduling steps, and able to use different filter pipeline, with different parameters in each step. A typical scheduler will be single stepped. The flavor_families config options are stored in JSON blob, It is not 1NF, but in this case it will not be an issue. The flavor_families can have an additional JSON blob which maintained by the scheduler itself, it MAY change when the related flavor definitions are changing. See the caching and race related options later in <TBD>. 2.3 Scheduler helper table(s) Every flavor family can create one or zero record in the sched_helper table per compute_nodes. The helper table should have these attributes: 1, reference to a compute_nodes 2, reference to a flavor_family 3, max_flavor_size (int) The biggest instance from the family which is bootable on the host The field can contain the available memory or vcpu or a custom number. The domain of this field MAY be limited to the actual values supported by the flavor in the family. 4, metric (int or float/double) The value of this filed is depends on the scheduler class, by default it can be the available memory, it SHOULD be used for ordering, but the scheduler MAY use it for other purposes. NOTE: max_flavor_size itself can be used for ordering as well. 5, AZ name: Can make the AZ scheduler hint significantly faster. PK: 1,2 +IDX: (2, 3), (2, DESC 4), (5, 2, 3), (5, 2, DESC 4) Option: Use different tables for those schedulers which uses 3 or 4 for ordering, for limiting the number of indexes. Option: Add DESCENDING index to max_flavor_size as well. 2.3.1 sched_helper_attr_<type> A scheduler MAY populate an additional attribute table, based on the filters needs. 1, reference to a flavor_family 2, reference to a compute_nodes 3, filter_key (str) (NOT NULL) 4, filter_sub_key (str, NULL allowed) 5, value (type, for ex.: int or str) PK: 1,2,3,4 (HASH IDX?) FK: 1,2 Option Use integer PK on sched_helper and use it as FK. 2.4 Flavor family 1, It needs to have a name or id or both 2, It needs to specify a group of hosts which can be considered as host (it can be an aggregate) 3, It needs to have some parameter for the scheduler, for example.: a class_name , NOT NULL 4, sched_config TEXT/BLOB/JSON 5, flavor_cache TEXT/BLOB/JSON 6, uses_helper_table bool True if the scheduler maintains sched_helper table regarding the family, In this case 3 cannot be NULL. 7, defer bool False: The scheduler creates the instance records, The boot request is blocked until a successful pick. True: The scheduler does not blocks boot request, it is called after the API service returned. PK: 1 IDX: (2,1) The Flavor Family is an admin only concept, It does not needs to be visible to the end users. It needs to be exposed on the admin API. class_name always needs to be specified, the class needs to verify the sanity check the flavor_family record. Option.: Using config files. NOTE: non-public flavors frequently uses dedicated servers at the provider, some user does not likes to share on the same baremetal host. 2.4.1 Managing the new tables When the helper table needs to change ? - When an instance booted or deleted. - When new a compute_node - cames up, disappears - disabled / enabled - looses/gaining trust NOTE: compute_node die estimate 100/day @ 100k host, if each have 1:1000 chance to die on the given day, so it is rare event. - When a relelvant aggregate or config option changes - AZ - cpu/memory/disk over commit ratio - At other scheduling related aggregate option change Note.: Hypervisor die estimate 100/day @ 100k host, if each have 1:1000 chance to die on the given day. The helper table records SHOULD be managed without reading them: `INSERT..ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE` or `DELETE`. When filling the helper table all filter in pipeline needs to be considered. The table only able to help for static filters. NOTE: The n-cpu normally does not updates the resource, but now we have bug which makes it reporting even if there is no change. https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1436986 2.5 Is the record existence in the helper table sufficient for static filtering ? In many cases yes, but special cases can exists when other boot parameters needs be considered. Let's see one of the tricky cases and our options: You would like to use SR-IOV with all virtual network, you can boot instances with 1-8 NIC, usually a physical NIC can have 64 vNIC functional unit / per physical port (2 rx/2 tx queue/vNiC ?), You would like to use ONLY the SR-IOV interfaces and you do not want use them if they are on remote NUMA node. This is tricky because of two reason: 1, It is a dynamic filter 2, The relevant information stored in JSON blobs The hypervisor can support more than 8 vNIC, but you can setup a reasonable limit per instance. The nodes with zero available vNIC MUST be excluded from the helper table in all cases. Solution A: - Size your physical/virtual machines properly. A NIC usually can have 2 ports (128 vNIC / numa node), you can have multiple 8x gen3 PCIe device per NUMA node. Consider the vNIC/RAM ratio and use smaller memory servers for small memory flavors (different flavour group) and big memory servers, for big memory flavors. Solution B.: - Consider the host bad when it does not have at least 8 VNIC at all NUMA node (or on the one which has the most available resources), when the flavor needs other PCI devices like GPU it can be more tricky. Solution C.: - Regarding to the helper table record, you add an additional attribute regarding to this. Solution E.: - Freeing the relevant information from the blobs, and the query will check for the required devices is available in the right place. Solution F.: - You will do post filtering in python after the main query as before this spec, but on much less record than you did it before, because other filters dropped the irrelevant records on the DB side, including the one which checked is the host has at least one device. 2.7 Three phase scheduling attempt The scheduler is allowed to use multiple strategy in order. - Pre query: A method which runs before the normal scheduling, It can be used for 'soft hints'. Looks like all existing filter is strict, so typically we need only - Main scheduling: The regular scheduling. - Post attempt: This is an optional part of the scheduler, it is done ONLY when otherwise the scheduler was unable to pick any host, because all host which normally hosts the flavor is fully utilised. Instead of ERRORing the instance or rejecting the boot, the scheduler MAY try to find a more expensive place. For example: If the user requested a vm with magnetic ephemeral disk, but he gets SSD on a host which also has GPU. The config in the flavor family MAY contain an ordered list of host groups which can be used in this case. 2.8 Weighting There are multiple options, all can be used together or separately. 2.8.1 Pre query If there is a `dynamic` property at boot and just very small amount of hosts can satisfy it, but it requires to use host properties which did used when we populated the metrics in the helper table, we can query the high benefit hosts before the main query. Such dynamic property can be the `DISK size + image UUID`, to avoid downloading an image from glance, or for other cache utilization. Network id(s) to avoid east-west traffic overhead. 2.8.1 AZ pick The scheduler MAY pick a AZ explicitly if it is non specified. It can be based on - volume usage. - tenant id modulo - AZ utilization - multiple from the above 3. 2.8.1.1 Volume usage If the VM requested to boot with an existing volume or when it's creation, done on behalf of the boot request AND the volume also belongs to the AZ. The schedule SHOULD ensure the VM and the Volume are in from the same AZ. This assume consistent AZ naming across the volume and compute services. 2.8.1.2 Tenant id based splitting The AZ pick can be simply just the modulo of the tenant id. Same tenant usually uses the same network, so it implicitly limits the cross AZ traffic. 2.8.1.3 AZ utilization We MAY maintain a table - AZ - Flavor-familiy - current-utilization - max utilization The utilization can be the used/available memory. It can be updated at instance spawn/delete, however it implies a lock which causes scheduler serialization /AZ/flavor_family. Option: it can be updated by a nova-manage cron job. Option: all worker updates it, with high periodicity (1h) in randomized way. Option: The processes with scheduling role agrees in instance which actually responsible for this task. The serialization /AZ/flavor_family looks like an acceptable limitation. The AZ selected by the scheduler should be considered as soft hint, and it SHOULD retry the search without AZ limit if he was wrong. 2.8.2 Static metric Not to be confused with the existing metric named things in the repo, it MAY be renamed to static_weight. The helper table will contain a metric field, how it will be used or being used depend on the scheduler class and config options. It can be a value based on statically available information, which can involve already existing data from the database, for example: - CPU usage (from the old metric) - Number of iops instances used - Free ram - ... 2.8.2.1 Static metric without the metric field - free ram or free vcpu based best-fit and worst-fit (fair-fir) strategies can use the max_flavor_size value alone, without actually using or population the metric field. - If the scheduler does not uses helper table for example the free_ram_mb attribute on the hosts table can be used. 2.8.4 Mixed metric You select a limited (~1000) number of host based on a Static metric, and you do a complex calculation and/or advanced queries regarding to the limited set only, Other things like ceilometer/telemetry data can be considered as well. It is good compromise between not parsing the full instances table (yes, not host table, the big instance table), and making decision based on that. This strategy MAY be extended to use other helper tables, related to the physical network topology. 2.9 Service Group Drivers The scheduler group drivers needs to be improved, in order to upgrade the database only when the host availability really changed. (It will be a separated spec.) https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1437199 The n-cpu normally does not updates the resource, but now we have bug which makes it reporting even if there is no change. https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1436986 2.10 Multiple node request It can be supported, the LIMIT used in the main query will be increased by the number of the requested nodes. Every instance -> host pick needs to consider the resource usage changes because of the previous instance -> host picks. All requests node expected to use the same flavor as it is available on the API. NOTE.: It MAY involve helper methods specified on the filter classes. 2.11 Multiple scheduler in parallel Scheduler needs be aware other scheduler instances or an instance delete MAY changed the host resource usage at the mean time. For avoiding all unexpected behavior a sched_cnt (default=0) attribute needs to be added to compute_nodes table. The resource claims on compute_nodes is done behalf on the scheduler, before updating any other record, the sched_cnt needs to be increased exactly by one, all compute_nodes attribute needs to be in the UPDATE related to the resource usage needs to include the previously know state in the WHERE part, in order to check for concurrent update. NOTE.: Usually the instance DELETE is not a real issue, but other new instances are. The scheduler MAY fetch more then one host even if just needs to pick host for one vm. For Example: LIMIT 8. If a concurrent update happened, the scheduler can try to use other already fetched host. If all fetched host failed to update scheduler MAY re-read the related records, by using the 'SELECT..FOR UPDATE' or 'SELECT..WITH SHARED LOCK'. The scheduling can be repeated at Multiple node request, scheduler can retry the full process as long as at least one new vm scheduled in each iteration. 2.12 Not having dedicated scheduler process If the scheduler is able to run in parallel, we should stop having a dedicated scheduler processes. The API processes can handle the user boot requests himself. The requests arrived via an rpc_call, can be handled on behalf of the conductor process. NOTE: The nova boot has --min-count, --max-count option, if the scheduling done behalf of the n-API and it is not able to pick at least min-count instances, it SHOULD refuse the boot request. The not scheduled vms needs to move to the ERROR state or the request needs to be refused. 2.13 NUMA memory utilisation and cpu pining 2.13.1 Memory allocation for numa VM The numa flavor spec explicitly disallows letting numa flavors to run a non-numa host. I disagree with this approach. Allocating memory from multiple NUMA node for a single vm is bad for the VM, when your VM's CPU requirements can be satisfied with a single physical CPU and there are other vms on the same host. (nr_vm>nr_numa_node) The Host NUMA generally has a total memory bandwith advantage. For example you have 8 memory channel instead of 4. If multiple vms sharing on the same memory channels you loose the advantage. If you really need more than 4 channel memory bandwith, you need to have a flavor which utilises more than a single physical CPU. 2.13.1 CPU pining: There are two possible strategies 2.13.1.1 Not exact pining Just have the host threads to run on the same NUMA node which exposed to the guest also as a some NUMA node. This allows the host linux scheduler to pick an idle cpu thread on the host and avoids the vary expansive NUMA misses. This strategy is good, when you allow cpu overcommit. It also makes the scheduling simple. 2.13.2 Exact pining The vcpu threads has affinity only to single physical cpu thread. This strategy is usfull when you do not do CPU over-committing, otherwise you have the guests to wait for CPU, even when the host linux scheduler would be able to help, and actually let you tu use an idle thread. Does the scheduler needs to know about the already utilised threads ? The pining can be changed at run time. A pining change usually also requires page migration, which might be visible on the guest side. The effect much smaller than a live migration, but very sensitive micro benchmarks may detect it. If we allow repining is the total number of available vcpu enough for scheduling? With some crazy flavor it is not enough, for example.: You have a host with 2x(2x8) vcpu, it has a VM with 2x12 cpu and you need to run a vm with 1x8 cpu, it will not work, 2x4 could work. Is it enough to know the minimum available vcpu per numa node + total available vcpu ? Just filling the flavor_family table probably enough, but the scheduler needs to be able to recalculate the exact usage when multiple vm scheduled to the same host. If we use any NUMA aware pinning strategy, the guest should know the NUMA topology in-order to have guest CPU scheduler to work properly. NOTE.: Almost every nova scheduling problem can be simplified by right flavor and compute node sizing. 2.14 When do we need to update anything in the sched helper table? When the helper table needs to change ? 1. When an host picked 2. When an instance deleted 3. When a compute_node - cames up, disappears - disabled / enabled - looses/gaining trust NOTE: compute_node die estimate 100/day @ 100k host, if each have 1:1000 chance to die on the given day, so it is rare event. NOTE: Maybe at interface or block device attach, if we consider its memory usage relevant and did not calculated with that at sizing. (The virtual disks by default has 16MB cache in memory) 4. At Flavor family or flavor changes. This operations is very rare and it could be very expensive. Generally many helper record needs to be updated or deleted in this case. 5. When a relelvant aggregate or config option changes - AZ - cpu/memory/disk over commit ratio - At other scheduling related aggregate option change Based on the flavor family class you MAY need to fetch all flavors in the family, but the flavor family record itself can contain enough information for avoiding this situation. The update at 1, 2, 3 leads to a similar frequent query: SELECT DISTINCT flavour_family.* FROM flavour_family,aggregate_member WHERE flavour_group.aggregate_id = aggregate_member.aggregate_id // eq joins AND aggregate_member.host_id = host_id WITH SHARED LOCK Option: We can add primary_group field to the host (compute_nodes) table. This still allows to use one host with multiple flavor family, and we will need to query less on 1,2,3 updates. The number of flavors and flavor families are small, the exact content could be cached either by the application or in memcached. If it would be cached in the application the problem would be how to invalidate the records without racing. Example.: If process1 cached the old flavor, but process2 updated the flavor, the helper table update done by process1 can be invalid as long as his cache is old to solving this would require to synchronously invalidate the caches on flavor related updates. The helper table records SHOULD be managed without reading them: `INSERT..ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE` or `DELETE`. When filling the helper table all filter in pipeline needs to be considered. The table only able to help for static filters. NOTE: The n-cpu normally does not updates the resource, but now we have bug which makes it reporting even if there is no change. https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1436986 2.14.1 flavor_family caching options The number of flavors and flavor families are small, the exact content could be cached either by the application or in memcached. The flavor_family needs to be read frequently. If it would be cached in the application the problem would be how to invalidate the records without racing. Example.: If process1 cached the old flavor, but process2 updated the flavor, the helper table update done by process1 can be invalid as long as his cache is old to solving this would require to synchronously invalidate the caches on flavor related updates. 2.14.1.1 Memcached with flavor families The flavor or flavor family updating transaction MUST invalidate(delete) the memcache record, immediately after it issued the first UPDATE statement. It MUST update the flavor before updating the helper table. Both MUST happen in the same transaction. The flavor and flavor_family always MUST be at least SELECTed with WITH SHARED LOCK. This ensures consistency. If the record is missing from the memcached it will not be updated with other processes because they will wait on the row lock. memcached SHOULD NOT be used in this way with galera multi-writer, galare does not do lock waits, so 3th process would fill the memcached with stale data. Galera in multi-writer mode is able to perform more READS than a single writer so it is acceptable. The SELECT..WITH SHARED LOCK is not needed if the admins does not do flavor_family changes, which have the flavor to behave completely differently. New flavor_families are generally ok, if this restriction followed by the operators it is safe to use cache even with galera. The system MAY have a config option to forbid fundamental flavor/ flavor_family changes, This can be ensured by the used scheduler class. 2.14.2 JSON parse cache Both the flavor_family has json blob parameter, which rarely changes. Each worker can maintain a json_string -> object cache, It can avoid a lot of parsing and instantiation work. 2.15 Query extender, Crafting The scheduler in each phase needs to use query, which gives back one or more comupte_nodes record or helper table record. 1. Static metric Iterate over the table which contains the metric, joining the required tables, Limiting the result set: - to 1 one scheduler worker - to 8 multiple workers - to 100.100 mixed scheduling 2. Dynamic ordering Filtering first, do ordering in memory on the DB side (just on ORDER BY <Expr>) Ideally each filter is able to extend the SQL queries filtering part, by the same thing what he is filtering. You can think in something like SQLAlchemy Query objects. The fetched record limit only needs to be high, if the filter does not able to help anything in a helper table creation, which can be based on a python only function. The situation can be avoided by all filter, but it needs to move out the values from the json blobs. 3. Transferingthe existing code to the new one 3.1 Scheduling boot steps for new VM(s) main function 1. flavor -> flavor_family fetch with SHARED LOCK 2. Instantiate the class get from the flavor_family, args flavor (with extra spec), and the family_record (with extra paramters) 3.a call the schedule() method with the parameters got from the nova boot API request schedule method itself creates the instances, and returning with them. (If the scheduler is part of the API service) 3.b The select_destinations() SHOULD be implemented with similar signature as before 3.2 Helper table update stpes for host changes If the host is down or disabled all related helper record needs to be DELETEd. At scheduling it is not tested, all host found in the helper table considered as up. 1. Find the relevant classes based on the host group info 2. call each classes update_host static method with - host_id - the paramters got from the family - the resource tracker info all info which is requred to determinate, is the host able to host the given flavor, and what is the max size and the metric - activity_test (bool) * when True: is the method needs to check is the host enabled and alive * False: The host is up , we will not touch the services table update_host SHOULD delete the helper record when the host does not able to handle the smallest instance from the family, it MAY reduce max_size to 0. update_host SHOULD NOT read the helper table, it SHOULD use INSERT..ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE (or just try UPDATE first and do INSERT when zero record changed). 3.3 Filter query extender Each filter SHOULD be able to extend a query which selects compute_nodes. The filters will be reordered (within the same extend type) based on how cheap they are, probably mysql planner itself is able to order the query only filter ordering. Note.: Mysql does not know INTERSECT. Note.: Mysql can be extended with a C library inorder to be able to produce or parse json. Note.: Mysql does not able to generate expression based indexes 3.3.1 Just a where on the compute_nodes table Non text blob fields (based on flavor) __tablename__ = 'compute_nodes' host = Column(String(255), nullable=True) vcpus = Column(Integer, nullable=False) memory_mb = Column(Integer, nullable=False) local_gb = Column(Integer, nullable=False) vcpus_used = Column(Integer, nullable=False) memory_mb_used = Column(Integer, nullable=False) local_gb_used = Column(Integer, nullable=False) hypervisor_type = Column(MediumText(), nullable=False) hypervisor_version = Column(Integer, nullable=False) hypervisor_hostname = Column(String(255)) free_ram_mb = Column(Integer) free_disk_gb = Column(Integer) current_workload = Column(Integer) running_vms = Column(Integer) cpu_info = Column(MediumText(), nullable=False) disk_available_least = Column(Integer) host_ip = Column(types.IPAddress()) supported_instances = Column(Text) metrics = Column(Text) # JSON ? pci_stats = Column(Text) # JSON extra_resources = Column(Text) # JSON stats = Column(Text, default='{}') # JSON numa_topology = Column(Text) # JSON 3.3.2 AllHostsFilter WHERE 1=1 3.3.3 SameHostFilter WHERE host = ? WHERE host IN (?, ? ,? , ?) 3.3.4 DifferentHostFilter WHERE host <> ? WHERE host NOT IN (?, ? ,? , ?) 3.3.5 DiskFilter WHERE free_disk_gb * CONF.disk_allocation_ratio >= flavor_disk_req flavor_disk_req = disk + ephemeral + swap NOTE: disk might be multiplied by 3 .: qcow + backing_sparese + differential_qcow 3.3.6 CoreFilter WHERE vcpus * CONF.cpu_allocation_ratio - vcpus_used >= requered_vcpu 3.3.7 NumInstancesFilter WHERE num_instances < CONF.max_instances 3.3.8 RamFilter WHERE free_ram_mb > flavor_ram_req /CONF.ram_allocation_ratio Useing div just to make obvios to the DB planner the free_ram_mb can be used if it part of a combined index. free_ram_mb index should be added to the compute_nodes table. 3.3.9 JsonFilter: It does very similar thing to the DiskFilter, CoreFilter, RamFilter Query creation is possible. 3.3.2 Joined flavor based filter 3.3.2.1 ComputeFilter: WHERE service.enabled AND serivcie.alive = True AND service.type = cpu AND service.host=compute_nodes.host //eq join serivcie.alive =True can be a date compare 3.3.2.2 AggregateCoreFilter, AggregateDiskFilter, AggregateRamFilter, AggregateNumInstancesFilter: Something like this.: WHERE comput_nodes.<attrname> >= requested_val / IFNULL(( SELECT MIN(FLOAT(val)) AS val_cnt FROM aggregates, aggregate_metadata,aggregate_hosts WHERE aggregates.id = AND aggregate_metadata.aggregate_id //eq join AND compute_nodes.host = aggregate_hosts.host // eq join, NOTE.: FK constainst is missing, but indexed AND aggregates.id = aggregate_hosts.aggregate_id AND aggregate_metadata.name = <wanted attr name> AND aggregate_metadata.deleted = 0 AND aggregates.deleted =0)), CONF.attr_ratio) NOTE: Long time ago mysql was better with implicit joins, needs to check how it is doing now. Some other DB was better with explicit joins and become crazy on mixing explicit and implicit joins. 3.3.3 Blob based filters This category where we would need to use either json parse native stored functions, or just a LIKE or REGEXP. The helper table is primary created for improving the performance with these filters. Some or all attribute can be moved out from the JSON text/blob inorder to be in a cheaper category. TODO.: evaluat when Not violating the 0NF and actually create new table or tables instead of the json definetly a better option. 3.3.3.1 AggregateInstanceExtraSpecsFilter, ComputeCapabilitiesFilter: Helper table population is possible, otherwise they need to be a post select filter. 3.3.3.2 NUMATopologyFilter total_vcpu/socket aka. nr_core_per_socket attribute ? is_numa bool attribute ? Per the spec text it denies non numa host usage, so the non numa hosts could be dropped at select time. 3.3.3.3 IoOpsFilter, AggregateIoOpsFilter: host_state is a BLOB. This is definitely the case when we should move out the value from the JSON basic helper table compatible, otherwise python. 3.3.3.4 MetricsFilter: Json key regexp query ? Since itself it just tests certain key existance, The helper table can be used as usual. 3.3.4 Other than flavor based runtime filters AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation: Is it real use case ? Normally the flavor_family and the flavor security should be served as having dedicated host. The filter might be usefull if there is company, where multiple department bought compute nodes, but some of the nodes are not in the shared pool what everybody could use with same flavor. filter_tenant_id is a string with a list of tenant ids, the DB can use the same LIKE as the filter. LIKE '%<tenant_id>%' I did not found a function like SPLIT(val,',') IN tenant_id It is possible too: CONCAT (',' aggr_meta.value , ',') % LIKE %,<tenant_id>,% Or just using a regexp. All aggregate needs to be processed. NOTE: The aggregate meta-data value is specified as `value` varchar(255) NOT NULL. 3.3.4.1 AvailabilityZoneFilter: The aggregate model allows to have the nodes in multiple AZ. IMHO it is not required, the host should be ONLY in one AZ exactly. The AZ should be specified on the compute_node. - Query possible - Helper table with attributes possible The value should be explicitly used as helper table. It is a thing what used frequently and it is able to drop 2/3 of the candidates host by index in a typical case 3.3.4.2 IsolatedHostsFilter, ImagePropertiesFilter, AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation - Query extender possible (dynamic) - Helper table with attributes possible 3.3.4.3 GroupAffinityFilter, GroupAntiAffinityFilter, ServerGroupAffinityFilter, ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter: JOINED with InstanceGroupPolicy, InstanceGroupMember, Instances, Compute_Hosts 3.3.4.4 AggregateTypeAffinityFilter,TypeAffinityFilter: query.: JOIN compute_nodes instances .. helper Table: Helper tables with attribute. Option: Just enforcing the same vcpu/memory ratio. 3.3.4.5 PciPassthroughFilter: The BLOB can be onverted to a table - host_id - vendor_id - product_id - pci_bus_id (which pci bus) - pci_bus_addr () The whole is a key candidate, an inter id can be added. After converting the BLOB to a table query would be possible. The tricky part is supporting multiple device allocation. If one flavor requires 1 GPU the other needs 2 it should be in a different flavor_family. Helper Table with attributes. 3.3.4.6 TrustedFilter: Uses a remote service for filtering, and a cache with cache validity time. The timeout is 60 sec, so it should not be part of helper, This needs to be checked after the select. If the flavor extra spec, does not reuires trusted host, this filter does nothing. 3.3.4.7 RetryFilter: Not a typical filter, its behavior might be incorporated to the basic scheduler strategy. If schedule request received via rpc and enumerates previosly failed hosts, those hosts should be excluded by a 'Dynamic plain WHERE' . 3.3.4.8 SimpleCIDRAffinityFilter: Postgresql is able to handle ipaddress type specially out of the box. Mysql can convert IPv4 or IPv6 string to Integer and do a bit mask operation. SqlAlchemy support ? Query possible, Helper table flags are possible NOTE.: Planning to create other type helper table to support networking, related placement even better, without passing a scheduler hint. Now details are out of scope from this spec. 3.3.5 Filter type statistics All available.: Basic plain WHERE: 7 Basic Joined WHERE: 5 Dynamic plain WHERE: 1 Dynamic joined WHERE: 7 BLOBed.: 6 Special.: 2 Lets see the default chain: RetryFilter: Not a filter AvailabilityZoneFilter:Dynamic joined RamFilter: Basic plain WHERE ComputeFilter: Basic Joined WHERE ComputeCapabilitiesFilter: BLOB (at compute_nodes) ImagePropertiesFilter: Dynamic joined WHERE (at property) ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter: Dynamic joined WHERE (at HINT) ServerGroupAffinityFilter: Dynamic joined WHERE (at HINT) 3.4 existing weighting and ordering capabilities highest weight wins. 3.4.1 IoOpsWeigher getting number of io instances form a JOSN BLOB. Helper table metric can be based on this. 3.4.2 metric weights https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/utilization-aware-scheduling - Default disabled - Depends on a periodic update Just cpu stats can be available at the moment, but the load itself does not. It also supports cpu util %. The periodic updates has some scale ability limit: probably you do not want to have more than 7500 Write transaction/sec from periodic updates. ~25% of the DB write intent tr capacity. If all periodic task has 60 sec periodicity, 450 000 task reaches the 25% capacity itself if they cause only 1-3 statement update transaction. The metric in the helper table needs to be recalculated if the formula references to these. If it happens in the same write intent transaction as the metric update on the compute_node, it does not have significant impact. The replicated DB has more issues with the number of write intent transactions, than with the number of statements. Instead of the existing cpu metrics I would like to suggest only one.: load_avg_5m / nr_cpu_threads (* 100 as int, or float) It gives you better idea about the load. 3.4.3 Ram compute_nodes.free_ram_mb based, looks like it is the most popular strategy. If nothing else used the select based on the hosts compute_nodes, can be as simple as .. ORDER BY compute_nodes.free_ram_mb LIMIT 1, and done. 6. Implementation The many existing scheduler filters will be incorporated to the helper table updates or to main query. The tricky filters will remains, and will be used at helper table population, in more tricky situations we MAY fall back to `at schedule check`. 6.1 Scheduler classes 6.1.1 Base scheduler class This is the one which will be specified in the nova.conf - Abstract version with documentation - rpc_remote Use a remote scheduler - local_scheduler The scheduling done on behalf of the n-api service. 6.2.2 scheduler classes This the class which actually does - the scheduling - helper table fill (With help of the filters) - Rule checks at flavor, flavor_type, aggregate related update 6.2.3 Add query extenders to the filters 7. How to use this in several not simple cases - Mixing no disk instances with SSD instances on the same nodes - Mixing GPU instance and CPU instances on the same nodes - Same host sizing , but with different vcpu/memory ratio and keeping the overcommit ratio promises (promised compute unit) as far as it is possible

commit_message:
Add previous page links for Nova GET servers API

This change is to support the v2.1 /servers and /servers/detail APIs
to support retrieving server data in the previous page and provide
the previous page link on the response.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164169/

APIImpact

Change-Id: Id84f226ddcdee01bc2cb023c7370bddf913fa543
Implements: blueprint nova-pagination-prevpage
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/41/165041/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Nova Pagination - Previous Page Link ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-pagination-prevpage Currently, the nova pagination only supports to provide the url of next page. However, we may want to retrieve the servers in the previous page. To enable backward query, the previous page link should be provided for the /servers and /servers/detail APIs. For more detail, please see Reference section. Problem description =================== There is no support for retrieving servers in the previous page. Currently, nova pagination provide the next page link in the 'servers_links', and we can only do the query forward. In order to retrieve data in the previous page, the /servers and /servers/detail APIs need to accept 'is_reverse' param to search backward and provide the previous page link on the response. Use Cases ---------- A UI that displays a page of server data. Users may want to retrieve servers data in the next page, while they may also want to retrieve data in the previous page. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== The /servers and /servers/detail APIs will support the following parameter once on the request: * is_reverse: determine whether to retrieve the server data in the previous page ('True' or 'False') The caller could specify 'is_reverse' to retrieve server data before the server specified by the 'marker'. By default, is_reverse is False. For example: /servers?is_reverse=1&marker=<uuid> And the previous page link should be added to the 'server_links' dict on the response. The basic idea of this change is to retrieve the previous server data by searching from the first item in the reverse direction. And the final result should be reversed to keep up the initial direction. Alternatives ------------ If we don't add another 'is_reverse' param, we could only provide the previous page link with reverse sort direction. However, the result will be in an opposite order. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The following existing v2 GET APIs will support the 'is_reverse' parameter: * /v2/{tenant_id}/servers * /v2/{tenant_id}/servers/detail The following existing v3 GET APIs will support the 'is_reverse' parameter: * /v3/servers * /v3/servers/details The existing API documentation needs to be updated to include the following parameter: * 'is_reverse': determine whether to retrieve the server data in the previous page ('True' or 'False') Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: wuhao Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Check if the 'is_reverse' param is valid * Pass down to the DB layer (change compute/api.py, objects/instance.py, db/api.py, and db/sqlalchemy/api.py * Reverse the sort direction if 'is_reverse' is True * Reverse the result of server data * provide the previous page link in 'servers_links' on the response (change openstack/compute/views/servers.py, api/openstack/common.py) Dependecies =========== None Testing ======= Add new test cases to /servers and /servers/detail API to test if server data in the previous page is returned when 'is_reverse' is True. Documentation Impact ==================== The /servers and /servers/detail API documentation will need to be updated to: - Reflect the 'is_reverse' parameter and explain that it will affect the page of server data returned. References ========== None

commit_message:
Delete children handle_delete testing (Ceilometer)

Delete children handle_delete correctness testing
for Resource's children classes.

This tests can be deleted because of testing
correctness of handle_delete in test_resource.

Also, small fix for overloaded handle_delete in alarms.

commit_message:
Allocate least feature device to user

This spec describes the blueprint pci-least-feature-match-filter

Change-Id: Ie6969a36f09b2fbc3aaa8d29db18d465143f01f4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/65/190065/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== PCI passthrough least feature match weight ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pci-least-feature-match-filter in cloud, there might have multi PCI devices in one host, and many hosts will have PCI device ready for passthrough/SRIOV. this bp provide a solution for pickup better host and better devices in the host based on the features the devices supported. Problem description =================== in current PCI passthrough allocation filter, the host and pci device been pickup only if the host meet the VM's request, not considering PCI device's feature, like physical netowrk lable. some time this will run out of device because PCI devices had more features run out. for example: host A had 1 pci device supporting neutron physical netowrk 'phy1' host A had another pci device don't have lable 'phy1' but same vendor produced NIC. host B had 1 pic device just same as host A but not support 'phy1' suppose user request this type NIC, but not use it for SRIOV, host A might allocate the device with lablel 'phy1' for user, this is wrong. and between host A and host B, select host B might be good choice, this behavior could be configrable via filter selection. Use Cases --------- 1. User want a SRIOV device and find it run out, but allocated them to who don't need the network. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== allocation the pci device for use in a better mach, allocationg the pci device just fit the reqeust, if extra features like 'phy1' provide, lower it's weight for allocation. the solution is a new filter for cross host problem and a sorted pci devices pool for same host alllocation. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None pci-least-feature-match-filter Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yongli.he@intel.com Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit testing, thirdparty CI test case. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Nova Server Count API Parameter

Proposes a new v2.1 REST API query string parameter that returns
the number of servers that match the specified search criteria in
the body of the existing GET servers reply.

Note that a /servers/count API extension was approved for juno but
this spec is being changed to return the count information based on
the existence of an "with_count=1" parameter; this aligns with the
API working group guideline for counting resources.

bp server-count-api
APIImpact

Change-Id: I282d6c6b2bf263543a2e6f9298c8ddbd49df75eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/79/134279/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Nova Server Count API Extension =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/server-count-api This blueprint proposes a new REST API extension that returns the number of servers that match the specified search criteria. Problem description =================== There is no current API that can retrieve summary count data for servers that match a variety of search filters. For example, getting the total number of servers in a given state. Retrieving all servers and then manually determining the count data does not scale because pagination queries must be implemented (see Alternatives section for a detailed explanation). Use Cases --------- The use cases that are driving this API extension are derived from a user's experience in a GUI. Use Case 1: A UI dashboard that contains servers in various states for a cloud administrator. A new API extension is needed to retrieve the server count data associated with various filters (ie, servers in active state, servers in building state, servers in error state, etc.) for the entire cloud. Assume that you have 5k instances in your cloud. The admin wants to see a summary of instances in each state -- this API extension will help them quickly determine if there is an issue that need attention; for example, if there are many instances in 'error'. It is likely that once the admin sees this count that they will then drill down into the data. However, without this new API extension, the admin will not know if there are unacceptable number of systems in a given state without drilling down into each set. From a deployer's perspective, creating this dashboard with the existing APIs is very painful since pagination is required (assume more then the default of 1k items). Also, processing time to get this data using the existing APIs (even the non-detailed) is slow (and possibly inaccurate -- see #3) compared to the processing time to get and return a single number. Use Case 2: Showing filtered data in a table in the UI. Assume that the UI supports tables that show filtered data (ie, table just showing instances in 'error' state) and uses pagination to get the data. Many users do not like "infinite scrolling" where they have no idea how many items really are in the list (more just show up as you scroll down or navigate to the next page). Using this new count API, the UI table can indicate how many total items are in the list (ie, showing 1-20 of 1000). Assume that you have 500 instances in error state and that you can open a UI table showing their details -- when creating the table, assume that the UI uses a page size of 100 and assume that there is no dashboard showing the 'error' count. In this case, the admin logs into the UI and wants to know how many servers are in error state. In order to do this, the admin navigates to the 'servers in error state' table -- the UI only retrieves the first 100 items so it impossible to know if there are 101 total items or 500 total items. As an admin, I would like to know what the total number of items in the table is. Use Case 3: Inherent timing window when adding a new item with limit/marker processing. Assume that you are using pagination to iterate over the data to get a count. When you are getting page n, it is possible that page n-1 has a new item x that was just added. Due to the sorting of the data, limit/marker will not detect that this new item was added. While this timing window is small, it does exist so getting an accurate count using this method is not guaranteed to be accurate. I realize that you can argue that the count API may not handle this UI use case either. However, the count will always be accurate from the DB at the time that the .count() function was processed -- the same claim cannot be made about getting the count using limit/marker since multiple DB calls are being invoked to calculate the number. Project Priority ---------------- None. Proposed change =============== The new count API extension must accept that same filter values as the existing /servers and /servers/details APIs and re-use the existing filter processing (once the common parts are refactored into utility methods that can be utilized by both paths). Once the filters are processed to create the query object, then the number of matching servers will be retrieved and returned from the database. The count API extension will be both per tenant and global (admin-only), similar to the existing /servers APIs. An admin can supply the 'all_tenants' parameter to signify that server count data should be retrieved globally. This new flow requires new functions to retrieve the count value in the compute API layer, in the instance layer, and in the database layers; all functions return an integer value. The naming conventions for the functions will follow the existing functions used for retrieving server instances, for example: * Compute API: get_count function * Instance layer (InstanceList class): get_count_by_filters function * DB layer: instance_count_by_filters function * Sqlalchemy layer: instance_count_by_filters function In the sqlalchemy DB layer, the filter processing (for processing exact name filters, regex filters, and tag filters) needs to be moved into a common function so that both the new count API extension and the existing get servers APIs can utilize it. Once the query object is created, then the count() function is invoked to retrieve the total number of matching servers for the given query. For the v2 API extension, the existing filtering pre-processing done in nova.api.openstack.compute.servers.Controller._get_servers needs to be moved into a static utility method so that the new count API extension can utilize it; this is critical so that the filtering support for the count API matches the filtering support for the /servers API. For the v3 API, a new count function (similiar to 'index' and 'detail') needs to be added to nova.api.openstack.compute.plugins.v3.servers directly. Common filter processing needs to broken out into utility functions (same idea as the v2 API). For v3, the 'count' GET API can be registered with the Servers extensions.V3APIExtensionBase directly. Alternatives ------------ Other APIs exist that return count data (quotas and limit) but they do not accept filter values. A user could accomplish the same result (less the timing window noted in Use Case #3) using the existing non-detailed /servers API with a filter and then count up the results. However, the primary use case for this blueprint is getting summary count data at scale. For example, if the total cloud has 5k VMs then doing paginated queries to iterate over the non-detailed '/servers' API with a filter and limit/marker is really inefficient -- the API is going to return more data then the user cares about (and do a lot of processing to get it). Assume that there are 2,500 instances in an active state; if the non-detailed query (and the default limit of 1k) is used then the application would have to make 3 separate REST API calls to get the all of the VMs and, at the DB layer, the marker processing would be used to find the correct page of data to return. Since the user only cares about a summary count, then the most efficient mechanism to retrieve that data would be a single DB query using the count() function. Note that the default maximum page set is set on the server (default of 1k); therefore, a user MUST HANDLE pagination since the number of items being queried may be greater then the default. There are other options for how the v2 and v3 APIs can be registered. For v2, the new count API could be registered by modifying the API routing in nova.api.openstack.compute.__init__.APIRouter directly (to create the /servers/count API just like /server/detail). Since v3 is still experimental, this blueprint is proposing that the count API is baked into nova.api.openstack.compute.plugins.v3.servers directly. I cannot think of alternative implementations. The new API needs to utilitize the existing filter processing as the current /servers APIs in order to ensure consistency and prevent dual maintenance. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- The response for the existing /servers and /servers/detail REST APIs will not be affected. * New v2 API extension: * Name: ServerCounts * Alias: os-server-counts * NEW v2 URL: v2/{tenant_id}/servers/count * NEW v3 URL: v3/servers/count * Description: Get number of servers * Method type: GET * Normal Response Codes: Same as the 'v2/{tenant_id}/servers/detail' API): * 200 * 203 * Error Response Codes (same as the 'v2/{tenant_id}/servers/detail' API): * computeFault (400, 500, ...) * serviceUnavailable (503) * badRequest (400) * unauthorized (401) * forbidden (403) * badMethod (405) * Parameters (same as the 'v2/{tenant_id}/servers' API except the 'limit' and 'marker' parameters): +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Description | +===============+=======+==============+======================================+ | all_tenants | query | xsd:boolean | Display server count information | | (optional) | | | from all tenants (Admin only). | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | changes-since | query | xsd:dateTime | A time/date stamp for when the | | (optional) | | | serverlast changed status. | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | image | query | xsd:anyURI | Name of the image in URL format. | | (optional) | | | | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | flavor | query | xsd:anyURI | Name of the flavor in URL format. | | (optional) | | | | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | name | query | xsd:string | Name of the server as a string. | | (optional) | | | | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ | status | query | csapi:Server | Value of the status of the server so | | (optional) | | Status | that you can filter on "ACTIVE" for | | | | | example. | +---------------+-------+--------------+--------------------------------------+ * JSON schema definition for the body data: N/A * JSON schema definition for the response data: {"count": <int>} Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None -- This new API is not introducing any new DB joins that would affect performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Steven Kaufer Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- * Move filter processing code into utility functions at the API layer and at the DB sqlalchemy layer. * Create new API functions in the various layers to get the count data. * v2 API extension and v3 API updates to expose the new count API function. Dependencies ============ Related (but independent) change being proposed in cinder: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-count-api Testing ======= Both unit and Tempest tests need to be created to ensure that the count data is accurate for various filters. Testing should be done against multiple backend database types. Documentation Impact ==================== Document the new v2 API extension and v3 API updates (see "REST API impact" section for details). References ========== None

commit_message:
Big Switch Neutron ML2 plugin integration

Add support for Big Switch Neutron ML2 plugin. Makes sure that the
package is present and sets up the [restproxy] section in ml2_conf.ini.

This also adds support for setting the ovs_use_veth option in
l3_agent.ini. There is no support for this in puppet-neutron l3 class
and it probably doesn't make sense adding it there, because this setting
isn't relevant for all l3 agent drivers, it's specific to
OVSInterfaceDriver. The ovs_use_veth option is also added to
dhcp_agent.ini.

Change-Id: I99635e25b2099dacce68154fe14693d6f06ac19f

added_lines: :: from mistral.actions import base class RunnerAction(base.Action): def __init__(self, param): # store the incomming params self.param = param def run(self): # return your results here return {'status': 0} 2. Publish the class in a namespace (in your setup.cfg) .. code-block:: cfg [entry_points] mistral.actions = example.runner = my.mistral_plugins.somefile:RunnerAction 4. Run db-sync tool via either :: tools/sync_db.sh --config-file <path-to-config> or:: mistral-db-manage --config-file <path-to-config> populate Now you can call the action "example.runner" :: my_workflow: tasks: my_action_task: action: example.runner parameters: param: avalue_to_pass_in

commit_message:
Fix task_state field shown on API < 2.5

After Share Migration was included, the task_state field was
added to be displayed on GET requests, but API versions prior to
2.5 should not see this field. This patch fixes that by using
microversions.

Closes-bug: #1494746
Change-Id: Ie755ae53fe8efdf1702a0ecbabf022a5fe4beb93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/45/223245/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _detail_version_modifiers = ["add_consistency_group_fields", "add_task_state_field"] @common.ViewBuilder.versioned_method("2.5", None, True) def add_task_state_field(self, share_dict, share): share_dict['task_state'] = share.get('task_state')
